title: ollie family need support give it back campaign
story: THERE are now  – count them – MPs jostling to be our next Prime Minister, so there should be plenty of scope for smart policy pledges over the coming days and weeks.High on the to-do list for any future PM must be plugging the £million shortfall needed to support disabled children and their families — as demanded by The Sun in its brilliant Give It Back campaign.Making this relatively small investment will mean huge savings for the Treasury and the NHS in the future.It will also clearly prove we value our most vulnerable children, and the families who love them — which is surely how any decent politician seeks to be judged.These include families like that of Vickey Kowal, whose moving story was told in yesterday’s Sun.She is mum to seven-year-old Ollie, who suffers from a rare condition where he regularly stops breathing.Vickey and husband Adrian go to bed every night not knowingtheir son will still be alive in the morning. But the family does not get the support it needs.Thousands of kind-hearted Sun readers have already signed Vickey’s letter to Chancellor Philip Hammond demanding he properly funds services — such as respite and overnight support — for parents with disabled children.We hope more of you will show your backing by signing the letter today, because the Kowal family are not an isolated case.Mums and dads up and down the country feel unable to look after their disabled children adequately because they are so exhausted — and they are frustrated at being let down by a system that is meant to help them.When we surveyed parents, just four per cent said they felt they had the support to safely care for their child.More than half have been treated by a GP for depression, anxiety or stress.Ollies grandad Dave helps out when he can, but the family are far from an isolated case - they need your helpIndependent Provider of Special Education Advice- for specialist legal adviceNewle - a charity that provides help with equipmentGOV.UK - to understand your childs entitlementsNational Autistic Society And a huge  per cent of children have gone without therapies, such as physio and speech and language help, meant to improve their lives.This lack of support starts right from diagnosis — with parents being left alone to come to terms with devastating news.They are then left to care for children with complex needs — often through the night — for months or years without any help or respite.This care is often emotional and stressful, and sometimes physical and back-breaking, too.At my charity, Contact — which works with families of disabled children — we hear all the time from those who have to fight for even the most basic provision.Disabled children and their families are desperately struggling because of a lack of support.We want the Government to reinstate the £m of funding it has cut from early intervention services - such as respite care and vital equipment.It is time for the Government to Give It Back.The number of disabled children in the UK has risen to nearly  million over the past  years - up by a third.But funding and support has been cut.Families with some of the most vulnerable children in the country are struggling to cope.That’s why we’re working with the Disabled Children’s Partnership to help them.Together we can make a real dference and hugely improve the lives of disabled children and their families.We want you to share your stories, email us on giveitback@the-sunPlease sign Ollie’s letter to put pressure on the Government to act now.These families are morally — and legally — entitled to help from local authorities, but it is just not forthcoming.It does not need to be like this. All the families want is a little amount of support to enable them to care safely for their child at home.They want a chance to go shopping, a moment to catch up on sleep or have a bath, or time to spend with their other children.This is not about pity or sympathy for disabled children.The families we work with cherish every day spent with their children, who bring real joy and have so much to offer. Instead, we are calling on the Government to help tackle the problem of the lack of support they are given.I have worked in the field of disability for  years, so I know that services have never been perfect.But cuts to budgets, combined with a  per cent increase in the number of children classed as disabled over the past decade, means we have reached a critical point — one where we need to decide what kind of country we want to be.We are talking about some of the most vulnerable children in society, and also children who have the potential to contribute a lot.This is not a campaign based purely on emotion, compassion or wanting to do the right thing, although those are all important.There is a hard-headed economic case here, too. Without putting funding back into services for disabled children, we can guarantee the taxpayer will be faced with a bigger bill in the long-term.That is because when families break down, children can end up in care or needing expensive crisis intervention from local councils or the NHS.Our families are amazing. When the chips are down, people can be remarkable.But most do not want to be amazing, or superhuman — they want an ordinary le.As Sun readers, you can give families up and down the country a real shot at that.Sign Vickey’s letter using this link, and ask which of our potential leaders will be first to agree to Give It Back.Amanda Batten is chair of the Disabled Children’s Partnership, a coalition of  leading charities, and CEO of Contact.Jane Harris, Director of External Affairs at the National Autistic SocietyWe want as many people as possible to sign the open letter calling on the Government to give back the millions that have been cut from support for disabled children. Thanks to The Sun and The Sun readers for getting behind this important campaign.”Dr Hilary Cass OBE, Chair of BACDEvery professional working in the field of childhood disability will be grateful to The Sun for launching the Give it Back campaign.Naseem Waker, mum of Leila, sevenThe Give It Back campaign shows the stark reality of a very complex situation. I am delighted a paper with the clout of The Sun has taken up the cause. Dan White, writer and broadcaster, dad of Emily, It’s  and parents and children in our community are like ghosts to society. We live amongst you, breathe your air, look at the same stars, but you do not know us. Today, you must finally make the country aware.Tracy Williams, mum of HarryThis campaign can transform the lives of nearly a million families with disabled children. title: pride month london 2019 parade events
story: But what is Pride London, where does it take place and what is it all in aid of  Heres all about this years event.The month-long Pride in London celebrations kick off this Saturday on June  and culminate in the city-wide parade on July .As always, it is showcasing the very best of London with theatre and cabaret shows, tours, exhibitions, conferences and museum events.This years events include Pride escape rooms, self defence classes, LGBT+ ping pong, le drawing  dance classes and the highly-anticipated Prides Got Talent competition.The talent show gives new and emerging talent in in London producer Tom Knight.Pride Month is not only celebrated in London, but across the globe.Pride is an annual celebration of the LGBT+ community .It is a huge event in London and around the worldIt culminates in the biggest LGBT+ parade in the UK, with thousands of people travelling the route either by foot or on floats.It aims to promote self-affirmation, dignity, equality rights, increase visibility as a social group, build community, and celebrate sexual ersity and gender iance. The the  Pride In London Parade is taking place on Saturday July , and starts at .pm.It starts on Portland Place, moves along Oxford Circus to Picadilly Circus and Lower Regent Street, before heading through Pall Mall and passing Trafalgar Square to Whitehall. You do not need tickets to go and see the Pride London parade.Admission is free to everyone and anyone .Under-s are welcome and the parade route is fully wheelchair accessible, although it can get very busy.There are dedicated volunteers along the parade route and accessible parking, as well as a viewing  and wheelchair recharging points at Trafalgar square.Assistance dogs are also welcome.PrettyLittleThing have announced their latest title: india rubbish mountain taj mahal environment
story: The fetid dump in Ghazipur, New Delhi, occupies the space of  football pitches and is home to hundreds of stray cows, dogs and rats who are seen wandering the stinking expanse.If it continues to grow at its current rate it will be taller than the iconic ft high Taj in Agra.Last year Indias Supreme Court warned that red warning lights will even have to adorn the dump to alert passing planes.Ghazipur opened in  and reached its capacity in  - but New Delhi sources say , tonnes of garbage are still being dumped there each day.Ahead of World Environment Day tomorrow, dozens of rag pickers could be seen scouring the rancid dump to salvage recyclable materials.In  two people were killed after a section of the rubbish dump collapsed in heavy rains.There are also fears the landfill has polluted the air and groundwater due to the toxic gases and liquid oozing from the pit, including methane belching from the rubbish.Fires sparked by methane gas also regularly break out, taking days to extinguish.Chitra Mukherjee, head of Chintan, an environment advocacy group said: “It all needs to be stopped as the continuous dumping has severely polluted the air and ground water.”Residents have been left struggling to breathe from the momentous dump.“The poisonous smell has made our lives hell. People fall ill all the time, -year-old local Puneet Sharma told the Times of India.Local doctor Kumud Gupta said she sees about  people, including babies, each day mostly suffering from respiratory and stomach ailments caused by polluted air, the Post reports.A government survey conducted between  and  reported that Delhi saw  deaths from acute respiratory infection while more than . million residents suffered from infections.Seven of the worlds  worst polluted cities are in India, with New Delhi ranked the worlds most polluted capital, a study published by AirVisual and Greenpeace showed.India, along with a number of other mainly Asian nations, was forced to take up the slack after China banned plastic imports - but then banned plastic waste and scrap in March this year.The country has vowed to completely phase out single-use plastics by .India has a low per-capital plastic consumption of kg a year - which is ten times as low as some other western countries.Prime Minister Narendra Modi launched Operation Clean India when he took power in , and has since had tens of thousands of public toilets built and introduced new waste management rules.However, watchdogs have repeatedly accused Delhis authorities of not taking the waste disposal crisis seriously, the Times of India reports. Earlier this year India banned imports of waste plastic in a bid to close the gap between waste generation and recycling capacity.It has also committed to completely phasing out single-use plastics by .

title: black hole clouds london asperitas
story: Incredible pictures show what looked like huge dents in the sky as the grey wavy clouds covered areas all over the capital.They appeared before the city was drenched by a day of rain following a weekend heatwave.City dwellers took to Twitter to question the bizarre phenomenon, with one comparing the skies to whipped meringues.Anyone  see this creepy cloud this morning  one tweeted.Another posted: Black hole formations from the clouds above London, are they warning of a black hole we are to be consumed by... They were only named in , making them the newest cloud type.Its not clear how these clouds are formed, though some experts believe they are formed after thunderstorms.Atmospheric conditions must be unstable to form a wavy cloud base like those scene with Asperitas.But the clouds have also been sighted in clear weather.Another wrote: Good cloud over north London. Looks like a giant wave.The Met Office said the clouds look like a rare formation called Asperitas.A spokesperson said: Asperitas is a distinctive but relatively rare cloud formation that takes the appearance of rippling waves.These wave-like structures form on the underside of the cloud to make it look like a rough sea surface when viewed from below.It is not known how the clouds are formed but they are thought to appear after thunderstorms.Last month Londoners were puzzled when a cloud shaped like the Euro sign appeared over Buckingham Palace.

title: d day landings 75th anniversary colourised pics
story: The extraordinary bravery of the men who took part has been highlighted in a series of stunning colourised images to commemorate the th anniversary.Striking shots show American and British troops arriving on French beaches for the invasions, D-Day Invasion glider pilots on landing craft and British Airborne Pathfinders at Harwell checking their watches on the night of June , .Other vivid colour pictures show Nazi General Erwin Rommel inspecting his defences, a German Panzer VI Tiger I Tank camouflaged in the undergrowth in Villers-Bocage, Normandy and men of the British nd Independent Parachute Company, th Airborne Division being briefed for the invasion.The original black and white photographs were painstakingly colourised by electrician Royston Leonard, ,  from Cardf, Wales, with each snap taking between four and five hours to complete.Hundreds of veterans will take part in commemorative events throughout the week— including those currently sailing from Dover on board the MV Boudicca to Normandy on a six-day voyage.More than  veterans boarded a ship chartered by the Royal British Legion to set sail across the English Channel ahead of the anniversary on Thursday.Many of the men who served - now all in their s - willto the beaches  years after the historic D-Day.Today, Theresa May will be joined by the leaders from every country that fought alongside the UK in the Battle of Normandy with the Queen, Prince Charles, members of the Armed Forces and  veterans.Donald Trump will also attend during his state visit to the UK.May sad she vows “never to forget” those who fell on the Normandy beaches  years ago.She said: “The Normandy landings  years ago were a moment of historic international co-operation.“And it is right that at the heart of today’s commemorations are the veterans who fought to secure the liberty and the peace that we now enjoy.“The global challenges we face today are dferent in their origin and nature.“But as we confront new and evolving threats to our security, it is more important than ever that we continue to stand together in upholding our shared values and way of le.“That’s why the UK has this week committed our Queen Elizabeth-class aircraft carriers and F- fighter jets to support the efforts of Nato forces to preserve the security and collective defence of our allies.“As I host leaders from around the world today to mark this signicant moment in our shared history, we will together reflect on the continued importance of the Western alliance for all our countries’ security and prosperity.Troops seen at Saint-Aubin-sur-mer on Juno Beach in Normandy during the D-Day landings of US Army th Infantry Division Troops on Utah Red Beach D-Day Normandy June ,  marks the th anniversary of the D-Day landings in Normandy when more than , servicemen began the push to liberate France.Ships gathered in the middle of the English Channel at point called Piccadilly Circus before making their way to the Normandy beaches.Paratroopers land behind enemy lines before the main assault begins with British soldiers tasked with securing the Benouville bridge on the Caen canal with Lieutenant Den Brotheridge leading the charge.He becomes the first Allied soldier to die in the assault when he is hit in the neck by machine gun fire.US paratroopers land with the aim of securing the town of Sainte Mere-Eglise, which is on the main road to Cherbourg which is the first French town to be liberated after hours of fighting.Allied warships start to open fire on the German sea defences with HMS Warspite firing off a broadside which marks the British and Canadian assault on Juno, Sword and Gold Beaches.US forces land on Utah and Omaha Beeches and come under fire from Nazi troops.By around midday commandos and troops finally reach the key bridges after heavy fighting to meet up with the paratroopers.Prime Minister Winston Churchill addresses the House of Commons.He tells MPs: “During the night and the early hours of this morning the first of the series of landings in force upon the European continent has taken place.”Read the remarkable stories of the ing veterans from our superb souvenir pulloutHow D-Day unfolded

title: peterborough by election latest win brexit party mike greene
story: The election on June  is taking place to replace disgraced former Labour MP Fiona Onasanya who was ousted after lying about her speeding ticket. story: In  six per cent of people had intentionally harmed themselves at some point in their le, according to a new study published in The Lancet Psychiatry.Thats up from two per cent in  - with the highest rate among girls and women aged  to .Emma Thomas, chief executive of charity YoungMinds, described the figures as alarming.The study provides the first evidence of long-term trends in non-suicidal self-harm in England, the researchers said.But self-harm can be an early warning sign that somebody may go on to attempt suicide, which is why its important to talk about it.The Sun professionals can discuss the subject with them and support better emotional health.Previous studies have used data from health services to measure self-harm, but many people who self-harm do not seek treatment.The proportion of people who said they had no contact with medical or psychological services after self-harming was . per cent in , . per cent in  and . per cent in .Ms Thomas said: The rise in rates of self-harm - particularly among girls and young women - is alarming.At the moment, its far too dficult for children and young people to get mental health support before they reach crisis point.The Government has promised extra investment, which must make a real dference to frontline services - but we also need to see action so young people can get early support in their communities.Jacqui Morrissey, assistant director of research and influencing at Samaritans, said: Self-harm is a sign of serious emotional distress and while the majority of people who self-harm will not go on to take their own le, it is a strong predictor for future suicide risk.Its therefore vital that there is a broad public health approach, rooted in education across frontline professionals and the wider community, improved mental health services and effective support on and offline.

title: d day veteran 97 parachutes normandy
story: Tom Rice, of San Diego, joined other jumpers to commemorate the World War II operation as thousands watched them softly floating through the bright skies.The American hero, who served with the st Airbone, jumped into Normandy with thousands of other parachutists in , and recalls it as the worst jump I ever had.Tom said: I got my left armpit caught in the lower left hand corner of the door so I swung out came back and hit the side of the aircraft swung out again and came back and I just tried to straighten my arm out and I got free.Today, the fearless US veteran jumped in tandem with another parachutist and has been preparing for the last six months, working with a physical trainer.Like many other war heroes, Tom said he remains troubled by the bloody conflict.He said: All the GIs suffer from same blame and shame. It bothers us all the time for what we did.We did a lot of destruction, damage. And we chased the Germans out and coming back here is a matter of closure. You can close the issue now.With the throb of their engines rumbling through cloudy skies, C- transport planes in WWII colours dropped jumpers with round canopies similar to those used in .Their landing zone for todays operation was fields of wildflowers outside Carentan, one of the objectives of the thousands dropped over Normandy as a prelude to the seaborne invasions on June , .Many spectators are wearing WWII era unorms and music of the time plays over loudspeakers, giving the display a s air.Other jumps are planned later today involving British veterans at Sannerville as part of events marking the th anniversary of the D-Day invasion.The anniversary of the Normandy landings is being marked by a series of events this week, with Prince Charles, Donald Trump and Theresa May travelling to France for the occasion.The invasion marked the beginning of Europe’s liberation and the eventual defeat of the Nazi regime.

title: pneumonia gonorrhoea bugs dirty bed sheets
story: But many of us are guilty of not changing our sheets regularly enough.Whilst you may think that popping them in the wash every three or four weeks is enough, experts say its not enough.In fact, new research has proven that bacteria linked to pneumonia and gonorrhoea starts growing in your bed within seven days.Last year British bed retailer TimeSleep conducted a survey which revealed that one in four of us wait as long as a month to wash our bedding.So they decided to carry out an experiment with the help of the University of Sevilles Department of Biology to see what a four-week-old bedsheet looks like under the microscope.Willing volunteer, Jess, was asked to sleep in the same bed for  nights straight and not wash or change the sheets, pillowcases or duvet cover.The team collected samples from three areas - the pillow, the middle of the bedand the bottom , at the end of each week.The samples were then sent off to the lab in Spain, where they were tested for bacteria and photographed under a microscope.Their findings by week four revealed an alarming list of dangerous bacteria growing inside the petri dishes.Among them were bacteroidales, which has been linked with pneumonia, gonorrhoea, and appendicitis.They also found fusobacteriales, known to cause throat infections leading to Lemierre’s syndrome, and neisseriales, which can cause gonorrhoea.When tracked back to the original source, bacteria were found to come from everything from human skin and the oral cavity to human stool.Luis, from the Biology Development Centre, said: “The sources of this microorganism have been tracked and it has been determined that the microbial ecology of the pillowcase and sheets came from human skin, oral cavity, and stool.“The family of actinomyces is the most abundant bacteria found in the bedsheets in general and these were found in the area of the feet.Members of clostridiales, bacteroidales, fusobacteriales, and neisseriales were found closer to the area of the pillowcase, although they were also common in the rest of the sheet.”The findings substantiate recent research from the North Carolina State University that revealed the ordinary beds of human beings have a greater ersity of bacteria than chimpanzee nests.Luis added: “Our findings compare favourably with the North Carolina State University paper published last year, which established a comparison between the microbial composition of human and primate beds.Strikingly, based on this study, chimpanzee beds show less ersity of microorganism than those that can be identied in human beds.”Jonathan Warren, chief exec at TimeSleep, said: “Despite the accepted habit that you should change your clothes every day, there is signicantly less attention paid to how often you should look to change your bedsheets.Given almost a quarter wait as long as a month, we decided to find out what meant for the hygiene of your bed.“The results highlight how important bed hygiene is to us all. Look to change your bedding at least every fortnight.If you don’t, you’re likely sleeping in worse condition than a chimpanzee.”

title: travellers head to appleby horse fair caravans
story: Traffic is currently at a standstill on the A near the festival site as thousands of revellers arrive for the annual event, which kicks off tomorrow.The Appleby Horse Fair is about buying and selling horses but it is also an opportunity for travellers to socialise and let their hair down.The fair, in the Westmorland area of Cumbria, attracts around , travellers every year.Signs are currently in place warning drivers to slow down for horse-drawn vehicles being pulled along the route, according to NewsStar.One red road sign warns motorists of injury from horses.It reads: Your safety cannot be guaranteed. Enter at your own risk.Earlier this week dozens of caravans and cars stopped on the grass verge of the A near Appleby-in-Westmorland.This year the local council has restricted the numbers allowed to park up and attend the fair, and increased police presence in the area.These steps have been made due to complaints from locals and motorists using the main roads close to the fair site.Last years festival saw  arrests,  crimes and  incidents logged by police.The earliest record of the fair is in a charter from Henry II, dating from the th century, but it is believed to have an even longer tradition than that.Sellers race and ride their horses up and down a main road to allow prospective buyers to assess their form and fitness.The washing of the horses in the river Eden in preparation for their sale is a tradition that dates back to the th century.Recently unearthed black and white photos show how the fair used to be celebrated in the s.

title: d day veteran john jenkins portsmouth ceremony
story: John Jenkins, , gave a moving speech at the D-Day commemoration ceremony in Portsmouth.As he walked on to the stage, the entire crowd - including the Queen, Prince Charles, Donald Trump and Theresa May - rose to honour him.Mr Jenkins was a -year-old platoon sergeant in the Pioneer Corps when he landed in Normandy on June , .He was deployed on Gold Beach, one of the five landing points on the French coast where Allied troops launched their operations.Mr Jenkins, from Portsmouth, told the crowd: I was terried. I think everyone was - you dont show it, but its there.I look back on it as a big part of my le, it changed me in a way - but I was just a small part in a very big machine.You never forget your comrades because we were all in there together.The veteran concluded: Its right that the courage and sacrice of so many veterans is being honoured  years on. We must never forget - thank you.Mr Jenkins joined the army in  aged just . After the Normandy landing he pushed on through France and Germany then helped to liberate the Fallingbostel concentration camp in Germany.Following the war, Mr Jenkins worked as a bus driver then as a crane operator at the Portsmouth naval base.He continued to serve in the Territorial Army for many years, rising to the rank of Company Sergeant Major and being awarded the MBE.The pensioner is a lelong fan of Portsmouth FC and has volunteered at the teams ground for decades.In a recent interview, he said his message to future generations would be simply: Lets have no more wars.Mr Jenkins spoke today towards the end of an hour-long ceremony in Portsmouth celebrating the service of the Allied troops who helped liberate Europe on D-Day.The Queen closed the event with a speech saying: When I attended the commemoration of the th anniversary of the D-Day landings, some thought it might be the last such event.But the wartime generation - my generation - is resilient, and I am delighted to be with you in Portsmouth today.It is the last formal part of Mr Trumps state visit to the UK before he leaves the country later today.Tomorrow world leaders including the President and Mrs May will be in Normandy meeting D-Day veterans on the exact th anniversary of the landings.I was  years old - sorry,  years old, I rolled my age back a bit - when I landed on Gold Beach.I was terried. I think everyone was - you dont show it, but its there.I look back on it as a big part of my le, it changed me in a way - but I was just a small part in a very big machine.Im honoured to be stood here today in from of many other veterans.You never forget your comrades because we were all in there together.Its right that the courage and sacrice of so many veterans is being honoured  years on.We must never forget - thank you.

title: wolf of wall street wannabe checks stocks behind wheel
story: Self-described financial trader Lee Davis, , shared a photo to his , followers, together with the caption: When traffic hits, I check trades.But a speedometer in the background revealed the Southampton Forex trader was travelling at mph.In another embarrassing twist, new details emerged that Davis was, in fact, banned from driving altogether after a drink-driving charge and dashcam footage caught him driving recklessly.The two-year ban - imposed in April - hasnt deterred Davis from fooling fans by posting old imagesof himself driving his eye-catching green BMW.But his eagle-eyed followers have been left less than impressed.One follower spotted the blunder and branded it illegal while others called Davis an idiot.One person asked: Does it give you back your licence for drink driving and driving like a pr*** though You drive like a pr***, risk peoples lives and you seem proud of you[rself]... another said.Confronted with the negative feedback, Davis retorted he had no recollection of the photograph of him driving while on his phone.Instead, the Wall Street wannabe claimed someone  posts to his social media accounts on his behalf and writes the captions to boot.He explained: This account is run by somebody . They upload pictures of me and put a caption on whatever they think suits it.Though Davis did admit recycling old photos in order to get attention.He said: Ive got a nice lovely car and I want to put pictures up of it.I do what I want. Its my Instagram. Its my cars. As I am banned, I will put pictures up of last year.Like I said, Ive got someone who runs my account and probably posting stuff as I speak now.The high-flyer, who claimed he earns a six-figure salary and has amassed a small fortune, makes regular attempts to show off his lavish lestyle on social media.Some photos show Davis flaunting Selfridges and Louis Vuitton bags claiming hed been shopping that day and using the same photo nine months apart.Others show a Rolex watch and a wad of bank notes.Accompanying one post is the caption: Earning money faster than you can spend it is the aim of the game. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madeleine mccann disappearance investigation funding home office
story: The Home Office has pledged to support the probe for another year, it is believed.Maddie was just three when she vanished from her familys holiday apartment in Praia da Luz, Portugal, on the night of May , .Scotland Yard previously revealed that a very small team are working on the mystery around her disappearance, and have asked for more cash to pursue active lines of inquiries.After a Portuguese inquiry into her disappearance foundered, the Yard opened Operation Grange in  - so far costing £.m.At its peak,  detectives worked on Maddie’s case, but the probe has been hugely scaled back in recent years and detectives reportedly made just two trips to Portugal in -.Those still involved with the investigation are now said to spend a lot of their time eliminating known sex offenders and chasing down potential witnesses.Most of what Operation Grange is doing is having things set up to knock down and rule out, rather than pursuing a particular fantastic lead that could unlock it all, a source told the Mail on Sunday.I’m not aware of any earth-shattering lead or breakthrough imminently.Despite a -year search for the missing girl, no trace of Madeleine - who would now be  - has been found.In May, Madeleines parents Kate and Gerry laid gts in her untouched bedroom today to mark her th birthday.They also hosted a party to honour the missing youngster at their home in Rothley, Leics.The McCanns wrote on the Official Find Madeleine Campaign Facebook page: Happy th Birthday, Madeleine!We love you and we’re waiting for you and we’re never going to give up.”A controversial new Netflix documentary re-examining Maddie’s kidnap was released last month, triggering a barrage of online abuse against Kate and Gerry by heartless trolls.They pair, who refused to take part in the eight-hour programme series, slammed it for potentially hindering the search for their daughter while an active police hunt is ongoing.For the latest news on this story keep checking back at Sun Online. Thesun is your go to destination for the best celebrity news, football news, real-le stories, jaw-dropping pictures and must-see video. Download our fantastic, new and improved free App for the best ever Sun Online experience. title: bgt alesha dixon final hand fart performer
story: “Is that it ” “Seriously ” “ grand ” “For one of that lot ”Never was it more true than the th and most sentimental series yet of Britain’s Got Talent, where the major talking point of last week’s live shows should’ve been Simon Cowell’s hair, which had been dyed a vivid shade of gorilla haemorrhoid black for the occasion.One David Walliams barb and a death stare from the boss, though, made it clear the subject was very much “off limits”.And Cowell probably had a point, as well.He knows that unless the judges act like the most credulous, gushing, “upped-your-game” morons in the theatre, then the whole show unravels.Nothing new there, obviously. It’s been like that since series one.It’s just that this year’s contestants forced them to be even more credulous, gushing and moronic than usual.Particularly the magicians, who were all doing iations on the same trick, with such little stagecraft, that one of last year’s rejects, Marc Spelmann, was deemed best of the bunch by virtue of putting on his X mask and saying nothing.It didn’t end there, however.Critical faculties also had to be suspended for a procession of try-hard comedians, pub singers, sob stories, village fete dancers and that Haunting thing which had Amanda Holden gasping, panting, yelping “F***” and Simon claiming: “It sounded like being next door to you on honeymoon.”Though probably not the fortnight inside Les Dennis’s static caravan in Rhyl.It wasn’t all bad, naturally.Someone almost held a tune, I’m sure, and there was a bit more tension to Jonathan Goodwin’s “Blindfold chick- en with crossbow”than there was about the Gomonov bird, who kept ducking out of the way almost every time her mate threw a kne.But what BGT really needs in such circumstances are dingbats like Gonzo, the fat Japanese tambourine frenzy, and Guy First, the Israeli bloke who can hand-fart the opening verse and chorus of We Will Rock You.He was born to be on this show, in fact, which makes what Alesha Dixon did during his semi-final appearance even more of a sackable offence. She buzzed him.She actually buzzed State Of The Fart, claiming he was “funny”, but she was “thinking rationally”.A very bad idea. Think rationally, Alesha, luv, and you might as well pack up and go home now, because the nut-fudge fringe acts are one of only two reasons this carnival of the mediocre is still going after  series.The other, of course, is the hosts, Ant  Dec, who may have fluffed the odd line but they never gushed or patronised, let alone talked down to the eventual winner, Colin Thackery.It was a majestic performance that came with a slightly unwelcome sting in the tail, on Sunday night, from Ant.“There’s a very special new show coming up later in the year, Britain’s Got Talent: The Champions. The finest acts from the last  years will compete against the best acts from around the world.” Dec: “Have they got a host yet ”Sell every share in the project immediately,ITV hasn’t got them both nailed down on five-year contracts. INCIDENTALLY,you watch only two shows this week, make them tonight’s finale of Chernobyl, on Sky Atlantic, at pm, and Harry Hill’s Alien Fun Capsule, Saturday, ITV, .pm, which features Oscar-nominated actor Sir Tom Courtenay playing “Michael Rodwell – blow ya top,” with Les Dennis.Gary Neville: “Both City and Liverpool have won  games, Liverpool ten games.”And Neil Mellor: “I wouldn’t say it was luck, but Spurs were certainly fortunate.”AND the  Soap Award for Most Hastily Arranged Holiday goes to . . .EastEnders’ Sharon Mitchell, who’d bought her tickets, sorted her visa, packed and headed off for Heathrow within  seconds of having the idea to go to Australia, last year.Just one of the many amazing storylines not honoured at the st Awards, hosted by Phillip Schofield, in Manchester, which someone on the red carpet described as a “Very Hollywood” occasion.Yeah, very. Even , to the best of my knowledge, The Oscars has never had a Best Bitch category.It’s no longer part of these ITV awards, sadly, and the ceremony’s gone all worthy, making the usual disapproving noises about sexism, championing mental health campaigns and acknowledging Hollyoaks’ Jack Reynolds, who’s set to become the oldest soap star ever, at , beating the previous record set by Corrie’s Bev Callard, who’s about .In another break with tradition, the Soap Awards had the chance to honour a genuinely brilliant episode of EastEnders, Shaki’s funeral, which movingly combined the character’s death with real-le victims of kne crime.I need hardly tell you, then, it lost the Scene of the Year category to an entirely forgettable Gail monologue from Coronation Street.The biggest missed opportunity of the night, however, possibly came with the “very special” gong for a member of the Emmerdale family.“She’s a faultless pro. . . one of the show’s finest ambassadors. . .  paved the way for female colleagues. So the Tony Warren award goes to. . .”Roxanne Pallett for Celebrity Bi. . .“Val Lawson.”Oh, OK. Maybe next year then HIGHLIGHT of the television week was arguably Gwyneth Paltrow’s spirit guide, Shaman Durek, attempting to perform “a healing process” on This Morning’s host Eamonn Holmes.Not a one-man job, by any stretch of the ­imagination.After a brief bit of finger clicking and some new-age waffle, though, Eamonn was sedated and Durek was commanding the spirits to “go into the access point in his stomach”, before asking: “Is there anything the spirits need ”Is there ever, Durek.Spirits, would you like a JCB Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsMeet the voters of Peterborough - where the Brexit Party could triumph tomorrowA by-election in crunch marginal Peterborough is held tomorrow. Will Nigel Farages new outfit scalp Labour and the Tories  Ben Glaze went out to take the temperatureShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsDick Rodgers bike, festooned with a big EU flag and flags of all  member states "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailVoters in Peterborough go to the polls tomorrow in a crunch by-election which could see Nigel Farageaposs Brexit Party win its first Westminster seat. Weary electors face their third ballot in five weeks after local elections on May  and the European Parliament poll on May . Brexit Party candidate Mike Greene is tipped to triumph in the marginal Cambridgeshire constituency, where % of voters opted to quit the EU in the  referendum. The ballot in the cathedral city was triggered by the ousting of MP Fiona Onasanya, who won the seat for Labour in  but was later jailed after lying over a speeding offence. The Tories held the constituency for  years from  when Labour reclaimed it by just  votes.    But the Conservatives have haemorrhaged support since failing to deliver EU withdrawal on March , making the seat a fight between the Brexit Party and Labour. Brexit Party activists were out in force in Cathedral Square today, their stall enjoying the most prominent position in the city centre, next to it its  rhythmic fountains. EU-loving Independent candidate Dick Rodgersapos bike stood feet away, festooned with a big EU flag and flags of all  member states. His sign read: “Common good. Remain in the EU. Please tell me why .% voted to leave.” A woman reading his sign said: “Remain in the EU  You must be bloody joking.” Mr Rodgers told the Mirror: “Lots of people take my leaflets, especially young people and minority ethnic people – not so much older people, but that accords with the national statistics and demographic.  “Iaposm very keen on what I say – the EU is a good idea, making a constructive spirit in Europe.” When his bike toppled over in the wind, an opponent from the Brexit Party gamely helped him right it. The Renew Party was stationed nearby, and one activist, struggling to handout his leaflets, apparently recycled his T-shirt from the Newport West by-election in April. The back read: “New party, new hope, Newport.” Labouraposs low-key red gazebo was hidden under four trees in the quieter Bridge Street, opposite the Town Hall and Mountain Warehouse. One wag quipped the position was apt because the party had a “mountain to climb” to retain the seat. Its stall had signs saying “For the many not the few” and “Your NHS safe with Lisa Forbes”. The candidate faced calls to quit the kne-edge race earlier this week after a new anti-Semitism row. Ms Forbes apologised for “liking” a post that said Theresa May had a “Zionist slave masters agenda” She said she was sorry for “wholeheartedly for not calling out these posts”. Labour activist Liz Bartley insisted the campaign was “going very well”.  She said: “The Brexit Party hasnapost got a manesto or any policies. “This election is about Peterborough, itaposs not about Brexit. “Itaposs about whataposs going on with our schools, our police, our social services, our health service.” Ten yards away was the purple and yellow UKIP gazebo with its banner: “UKIP for the nation.” A passer-by yelled: “Good morning, fascists and racists, how are you ” Candidate John Whitby blamed the Brexit Party for his likely defeat.  Denying he was “bitter”, he admitted: “We got a group here at the last minute which has rather taken the wind out of our sails.” The only sign of the Lib Dems in town by lunchtime was four youngsters in yellow rosettes scuttling along the edge of the square, not attempting to engage would-be voters. Busker Martin Plant, playing Fields of Gold and with about £. in his case, attached a Brexit Party flag to his guitar. Martin, , who ed to his native Leicester from Spain in the aftermath of the  referendum, said: “They are the only ones bringing our country back. “Iaposve never voted, apart from Neil Kinnock when I was . “I didnapost believe in democracy until it went away.”  Fteen candidates are bidding to succeed Onasanya. But bookies believe the battle is a two-horse race. The Brexit Party is   to win, Labour  , Lib Dems   and Tories  . One source said the Conservatives, whose candidate is Paul Bristow, had effectively “given up”. They were nowhere to be seen today. And there was little love for the Tories – or Labour – among voters. Louisa Berry, , a photographer, said: “Iaposm voting for the Brexit Party. “Everyone  seems to be messing things up and the Government needs a shock – this is the way to get the message across.  “I voted Remain in  but the country had its say, the vast majority voted to leave and we need to get on with it. “We canapost keep having votes until they get the answer they want.” Louisa voted Labour “until Jeremy Corbyn ”, adding: “I donapost like him, I think heaposs an idiot. “Heaposs very much along the lines of Trump in the fact heaposs got everything twisted. “I donapost like him as a person, I donapost think he would be good for this country. “He flip-flops on Brexit.” Gordon Richardson turned his back on the Tories and will vote for the Brexit Party.  The retired engineer, , said: “Itaposs the last chance weaposve got to get England back. “The Conservative Party havenapost done anything like what the people asked for. “Mrs May – and this sounds rather harsh – should have been tried for treason.” Looking ahead to the Tory leadership race, he added: “This by-election is a benchmark. “If the Brexit Party can get into Peterborough we will show Boris Johnson this is what the people of England really want.” Ivor Henson, a retired foundry moulder, will also back Nigel Farageaposs party, saying: “Itaposs time for a change. “Iaposve always voted Labour but the Brexit situation has put everything off. “Iaposve lived in this town since I was born – Iaposm  – but itaposs gone to the dogs. “The last Labour MP went to jail! “Labour hasnapost done anything, they just argue among themselves. They havenapost come up with an alternative.” He added: “I feel sorry for Theresa May, she worked bloody hard.” His we Shirley, a retired machinist who was also a lelong Labour voter, will also back the Brexit Party. “I want to leave the EU,” she said. “I hate the size of Jeremy Corbyn. Itaposs Nigel we are all for.” However, Remain-supporter David Richings, , a retired local government clerk, plans to vote either Lib Dem or Labour.  He said: “I voted for Fiona last time just to get rid ofStewart Jackson, a smarmy Brexiteer. “I didnapost vote in , I didnapost think there should be a referendum. “Iaposm dubious of Labour because Iaposm not sureLabour is a party of Remain. “I would describe myself as a Labour voter but they ought to get rid of Jeremy Corbyn and be a Remain party.” When the result is announced early on Friday, the Brexit Party could be sending its first MP to Westminster, piling fresh pressure on Labour and the Tories.

title: two dates ann widdecombes theatre
story: NewsTwo dates on Ann Widdecombes theatre tour cancelled after gay cure commentsThe Brexit Party MEP was scheduled to give performances in Penzance and Ilfracombe - but both dates have been pulledShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  JUN News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo dates on barmy Ann Widdecombeaposs stage show tour have been cancelled after she sparked fury with comments about aposgay cures.aposIt came as she rallied Brexit Party supporters with a pantomime performance in Peterborough on the eve of tomorrowaposs by-election.The new Brexit Party MEP - a veteran campaigner against LGBT rights - faced a backlash after claiming science may produce an answer to homosexuality. She was scheduled to give a performance in Penzance on Saturday. Organisers described the event as an aposI really wish Iaposd seen that kind of momentapos.   But they posted on Facebook last night that the event had been pulled.She was also scheduled to appear at Ilfracombeaposs Landmark Theatre in March next year. But David Hutchinson, CEO of theatre owners Selladoor, said he had intervened to cancel the appearance because of Ms Widdecombeaposs comments. Further dates next week in Lytham St Annes and Altrincham are understood to be going ahead as planned. Last night, the MEP, ex-Tory minister and one-time Strictly flop ranted against her former party in a chaotic appearance in Peterborough.  Wearing a pale blue rosette on her left lapel, she plodded along the Cresset Theatre stage as she raged about “three years of utter incompetence and lack of will” over Brexit by MPs. Warming to the panto atmosphere, the new partyaposs bizarre heroine asked  activists: “What do we want Peterborough  Brexit! When do we want it, Peterborough ” “Now!” came the reply. Her baffling entry to the by-election campaign came just days after she triggered fury by suggesting science could eventually cure people of being gay. But there was no mention of her offensive views on how to stop homosexuality as she urged supporters to back Brexit Party candidate Mike Greene, a former Conservative-supporting businessman who has appeared on Channel ’s The Secret Millionaire. She said in a weekend TV interview: “The fact we now think it’s quite impossible for people to switch sexuality doesn’t mean science may not yet produce an answer at some stage.”    But instead of ing to here theme, she focused on the impact a Brexit Party victory today would have on politics. “You will be sending shockwaves through Westminster,” she trilled. Shouting into a microphone in a haughty, Victorian school mistress voice ranging from alarming high-pitch to affected baritone, she pounded around the  saying: “We had have three years of fudge, confusion, obfuscation, misleading statements and getting absolutely nowhere, bot because something unpredictable and quite inevitable happened but simply because Parliament does not want to do what the country told it, it wanted to do.” Conservatives had “umpteen chances to deliver Brexit”, she insisted. While Miss Widdecombeaposs message and style will alienate many ordinary voters, Brexit Party fans lapped it up, including many who flocked to the rally from outside the constituency. Ben Rockclfe, , a student from North Cambs, said: “I thought it was good, Iaposve not really been involved in politics before or come to any rallies before but it has quite inspired me. “Iaposm interested in the Brexit Party and what they have to offer. “Hopefully they will get their first MP.” Brian Vowell, , a retired telecoms engineers of Southend, Essex, added: “She speaks the truth – MPs donapost speak the truth. “She was smashing and to the point.” His we, retired toy factory worker Jean Vowell, , said: “Sheaposs out of this world, sheaposs great.” Retired engineer Chris Edis, , of Peterborough, was “quite impressed”, saying the new party was “on the way up”. Revealing he would “definitely” vote for Mr Greene today, he said: “Iaposm fed up with whataposs happened about Europe. “We didnapost get the delivery we wanted.“I used to vote Labour years ago but I donapost likeCorbyn, not at all.“I would never vote for them while heaposs there.”

With Jeremy Corbyn and Theresa May in Portsmouth for the D-Day commemoration the dubious honour of PMQs was handed to David Lidington and Rebecca Long-Bailey. For reasons best known to Labour Kremlinologists Ms Long-Bailey was the understudy for the usual understudy Emily Thornberry The shadow Business Secretary is viewed by some of Corbyn’s team as the preferred successor should the Labour leader ever decide to step down. So this step up was an opportunity to gauge whether she is a potential leader in waiting or a victim of over promotion.  If there were any nerves, she concealed them well. This was competent performance that made you forget it was her debut. Lidington had some fun in his first response at Ms Thornberry’s “internal exile” after falling foul of the “dear leader” but for the rest of the exchanges it was Ms Long-Bailey who set the pace. Understandably, she played it slightly safe by sticking to her areas of expertise, climate change and industrial policy, but her questions were sharp and detailed. Scoring points off the unflappable Lidington is not easy. He has the manner of a vicar but one who, like Angela Rayner today, is prepared to wear bovver boots. Yet Long-Bailey made him commit a couple of unforced errors and neatly picked him up when he failed to answer her question on what the Government was doing for the steel workers. In her final question she combined an attack on the Conservatives’ failure on renewable energy with a big sell for her party’s green industrial strategy. There was fluency here that is often lacking when her boss is at the despatch box. Perhaps he should allow the understudies to take on the star role more often. story: NewsDad who won £m in lottery carried on working for year and holidays in SkegnessGordon Rees, from Nottingham, still looks forward to caravan holidays despite his lucky Euromillions winShareCommentsByRachel Gorman:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsGordon won £m in the Euromillions three years ago "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad-of-three who became a millionaire overnight when he won the lottery carried on working as a taxi driver because he enjoyed the banter and still holidays in Skegness. Gordon Rees, , scooped the le-changing £ million prize after buying a lucky dip entry while in his local shop in Nottingham, buying milk. He bought the winning ticket for the EuroMillions Millionaire Maker on June , , after a serendipitous chain of events.It started with his friend bringing him back some duty-free cigarettes, Nottinghamshire Live reported.He said: On that day, I didn’t need my cigarettes so I didn’t go to my usual shop but instead went across the road to the Co-op because I wanted milk and I thought itaposd be nicer than the corner shop one.    I went in, saw the price of the milk and almost walked out again, but then decided I couldn’t be bothered, walked to the counter with my money in my hand for the milk and my lottery. I had to queue - I think the shop assistant was having a bit of banter with a young lady in front of me - but I got there in the end, asked for two lucky dips on that nightaposs Euros and lo and behold, one turned out to be a winning ticket. It was just a lucky dip and I’ve done lucky dips ever since. I still play the lottery now. He checked his ticket in the advert break while watching a film, after a night of playing dominoes. He was so shocked, he called his daughter to double check. I couldn’t believe it. It was mind-blowing, he continued.    The next day we phoned the lottery people from the florist shop where my daughter worked at the time. They did all the security checks and said Congratulations Mr Rees, you’re a millionaire! But the money didnapost go to Gordonaposs head - he stayed in his job for another year, until his th birthday. He said: I’ve always enjoyed driving, they were a great bunch of lads at the company I worked for. I always enjoyed the banter and everything like that. Eventually, he took early retirement when the guilt he felt charging customers for their journeys became too much. I came to the conclusion that with all that money in my pocket, I couldn’t bear to take any money off my customers so I decided to finish, he added. When he won the money, Gordon had recently split from his long-term partner, had lost his family home and was living in a two bed flat on a council estate. The prize changed his le - he was able to buy a house, a car and has even been on a couple of nice holidays and treated his children.    But he hasnapost really splashed the cash and is excited to spend some time at his friendaposs caravan in Skegness. He did treat himself to some shares in his beloved football team, Notts County, after he had to grow up and give up his annual membership and season ticket when he became a dad, Iaposm living the le now, he said. I’m just a down to earth person who got lucky. Gordon says he has no current plans for any more large purchases and is happy with his busy social le. He is still single single and is thinking about booking a family holiday to Disneyland in the States at some point.

He was on Landing Craft  and left Portsmouth at pm on the day before D-Day, carrying Royal Marines and sailors on board.    I wouldnapost have missed D-Day for the world, the pensioner, from Bexhill, East Sussex, said. story: NewsD-Day hero, , whoops with delight on adrenaline-pumping ride  years onA group of  Normandy veterans have gathered together in Poole, Dorset to meet their modern day equivalentsShareCommentsByRachael Bletchly:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video -year-old-d-day-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAlbert Evans hangs on to his beret and whoops as the Royal Marine RIB bounces across the waves in high-speed donut turns. “What a ride! How fantastic!” yells the old soldier, , the wind carrying away his excited cries. Perched in the stern, two young marines watch admiringly as the pensioner from Dudley, West Midlands, takes the adrenaline-pumping ride in his stride. But Albert doesn’t scare easily. And nor do the  other  to -year-olds watching from the quayside and ship decks.    Seventy five years ago they dodged bullets, bombs and U-boat torpedoes as they stormed the coast of Normandy to turn the tide of the Second World War. And today, as they sailed into the peaceful waters of Poole Harbour, this spirited band of brothers got a heroes’ welcome from today’s naval personnel. The Royal British Legion-chartered MV Boudicca, which had sailed overnight from Dunkirk, was escorted into dock by three marine vessels as local children waved from the quayside. After disembarking the veterans and their carers chatted to young service-men and inspected their modern kit. Then Albert, who saw his Bren gunner pal Ernest being shot and killed in front of him in the weeks after D-Day, joined a handful of others taking thrilling boat rides.    On the quay former Royal Marine Commando Eric Carter, , of Birmingham, climbed up into an armoured vehicle. Serving Marine Christopher Takacs of Charlie Company,  Commando, demonstrated a new grenade machine gun that fires  rounds a minute. He said: “They’re our forefathers and we look up to them. They laid the ­foundations of what we are today ­especially in the D-Day landings.”” Impressed Mr Carter, who landed on Juno beach with Canadian troops on D-Day, said: “They weren’t like this in my day. It’s a nice piece of kit.” Coxswains of  Assault Group’s  Assault Squadron and troops also showed off their kit before sharing stories with the D-Day heroes. Veteran Trevor Stacey, Royal Marine of  Commando, chatted happily. Albert Barnes, , of Southend, Essex, inspected a modern weapon’s sights.  Royal Marines veteran Robert William Yaxley, , said: “I feel so lucky to be here. I landed on D-Day and went through to Germany without a scratch.It’s very important to mark this.” Aboard the Boudicca, Gordon Highlander veteran James Glennie, , of Aberdeen, tried a modern assault gun. The veterans are on a week long cruise marking the anniversary and will be in Portsmouth today for the official commemoration attended by the Queen and President Trump.    On Thursday they drop anchor off Gold Beach, Normandy, for services at Bayeux’s Cathedral and War Cem­etery and a march-past in Arromanches. Arthur Jones, , of ­Wolverhampton, drove a Sherman tank on to Gold Beach as he served with the th Essex Yeomanry. He said: “Another of our tanks had been blown up. The men hadn’t made it so I didn’t know what lay in store. I made it through though.” Eyes welling up, he added: “I think I’m going to get emotional standing in the cemetery at Bayeux on Thursday with the chaps who didn’t come home.” Arthur Bailey, , served with the th West Riding Infantry Division on D-Day then with the Paras at the Battle of Arnhem in September . He spoke to two local schoolchildren fascinated by his chest-full of medals. Explaining what they were for, he told the girls: “A lot of men died in the war, there aren’t many of us left.”    He went on: “It’s lovely that they are showing an interest. Youngsters today don’t seem to know much about it. Perhaps this will spark new interest.” Jack Mortimer, , from Leeds also made friends with a group of pupils. Jack, a dispatch driver with the th Ordnance Beach Detachment, had transported ammunition and mortars in his jeep on D-Day. But yesterday he stood surrounded by youngsters jigging away as they showed him the moves for toothless Grandpa Shark in the Baby Shark dance. He beamed: “Oh, how marvellous. I’ll have to remember this one.”    He added: “Today has been brilliant. I can’t really get the words out. It’s just tremendous to be welcomed like this.” Back on the Boudicca the veterans enjoyed a talk from TV historian Peter Snow and were entertained by magician Lance Corporal Richard Jones, winner of Britain’s Got Talent in . L Cpl Jones, , who serves with the Household Cavalry, said: “This is a really wonderful event to be a part of. “It is incredible and awe-inspiring to hear what these men went through on D-Day and throughout the war. “They are clearly having a great time, making new friendships and renewing old ones and having a real laugh together.

story: NewsRailway worker came within . seconds of being struck by a mph trainThe lookout worker was able move out of the railway track at about . seconds before the high-speed train struck him at Peterborough stationShareCommentsByTfany Lo:,  JUN NewsThe train driver managed to alert the worker by horning before it struck him "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA railway worker had a lucky escape after coming within seconds from being hit by a mph train. A report by the Rail Accident Investigation Branchhas revealed how the worker, who was working as a site lookout for a colleague,was aposdistractedapos when the high-speed train darted through the station. He would certainly have been struckthe train driver had not alerted the horn just in time. A series of recommendations have now been made following the near-miss in Peterborough on July , .    The report stated the worker moved out of the path about . seconds before the train, which was travelling at mphat the time, reached him. It also told how the track worker carrying out the inspection, who was also responsible for the safety of all the staff involved in the work, was not monitoring the unsafe actions of the lookout. Five recommendations have now been made to Network Rail, including ensuring that site lookouts stand in safe positions.    Simon French, Chief Inspector of Rail Accidents said: The number of near misses involving trains and track workers which we have seen in recent years is hugely disappointing. The catalogue of problems with on-site organisation and communication that we found in this investigation was alarming. Some of the people involved made assumptions about what was happening, and the lookout allowed himself to be distracted from the vital duty of warning of approaching trains. It is disappointing that the planning of the work had resulted in it being done while trains were running.    The investigation highlighted the dficulty of managing effective communications between controllers of site safety and the lookouts at locations remote from the site of work. Mr French explained: A number of unofficial flag signals were being used to transmit messages, and this was a factor in the Peterborough incident. For this reason, we are recommending that Network Rail investigates the methods of communication that are actually being used in these circumstances, and comes up with practical measures that will make le safer for teams working on the track.

title: sick dad sent final text
story: NewsSick dad sent final text to daughter then killed himself after DWP cut his benefitsPainter and decorator Kevin Dooley, , who was deemed fit to work by the DWP, texted his daughter “I love you”ShareCommentsByLucy ThorntonNathan Sandhu:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsKevin Dooley with daughter Leanne Dooley "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA desperate grandfather told by doctors he was too sick to work killed himself after his benefits were cut, an inquest has heard. Painter and decorator Kevin Dooley, , who was deemed fit to work by the Department of Work and Pensions , texted his daughter “I love you” before hanging himself. His daughter, Leanne Dooley, , found him hanging in his bedroom just days before Christmas last year and he died three days later in hospital. She told Wakefield coroneraposs court how she was certain his death was caused by his benefit woes. In a read statement, Leanne said: “I am of the firm belief the issues regarding my fatheraposs fitness to work and the subsequent stopping of his benefits had a very detrimental effect which resulted in worsening anxiety and depression and ultimately caused him to take his own le.” Department for Work and Pensionsassessors had written to Mr Dooley requesting a consultation in July last year and he was then declared fit to work. The decision was taken despite Mr Dooley suffering breathing problems caused by chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and doctors telling him he was too sick toto his job.    Mr Dooley lodged an appeal following the decision by assessors at Leeds Centre for Health and Disability Assessments, run on behalf of the DWP, but it was rejected. His employment support allowance was then stopped in November. His mental health suffered as a result and Mr Dooley feared he would be without money and may have to apply for universal credit, the inquest heard. His daughter planned to help him take his case to a tribunal. During the -minute inquest, a court heard Mr Dooley, from Leeds, West Yorks., had suffered from anxiety and depression since  and received the DWP letter in July . Mum-f-two, Leanne, , a pharmacy healthcare assistant, added: “At the time I tried to convince him not to worry. “Following an assessment, he was deemed fit for work and he appealed the decision but it was upheld. “The only option available to him was to take it to a tribunal. My fatheraposs payments stopped in November, he then had to apply for universal credit. He was extremely worried about not having money. “I visited my father on December , he was very quiet and worried. He was worried about his benefits having been stopped. “I had to leave him to go Christmas shopping and to pick my children up. I received a text from him saying love you. I knew straight away there was something wrong.” He was found hanging in an upstairs bedroom by Leanne who performed CPR before calling an ambulance. A decision was taken to turn off his le support machine and Mr Dooley died from a hypoxic brain injury due to asphyxiation secondary to hanging at Leeds General Infirmary on December th last year.    Doctor Caroline Abbott GP said: “He attended the surgery on August , , and was in a state of panic about his DWP medical in four days time. “It would appear Kevinaposs mental health was severely and adversely affected after the DWP told him he was fit to work, this affected his housing benefit.” Area coroner Jonathan Leach recorded a conclusion of suicide. He said: “It is apparent from Miss Dooleyaposs statement that issues regarding his fitness to work and stopping his benefits had a very detrimental effect on him and ultimately caused him to take his own le. “Kevin didnapost leave a note or any indication as to why he would take his own le so we donapost knowthat was the case.” Speaking previously about her dadaposs death, Leanne said he had been informed the £ a week and housing benefit entitlement he received would be cut. She said at the time he had three inhalers and “all kinds of medications” and would black out during coughing fits. “The assessor said he was fit to work because he told them he could walk to the shop sometimes and occasionally minded his grandkids,” she said. “But most days he was so ill he couldn’t get out of bed. No employer would give him a job because he wasn’t physically able to hold one down. “You only have to look at the news to see this is happening to many people. They are being deemed fit to work and killing themselves. It’s an absolute disgrace.” The DWP have been approached for comment. If you need to speak to someone, Samaritans are available   by calling   or by emailing jo@samaritans.org
