title: BBC new Tide show in Strangford Lough
story: STRANGFORD Lough is featured in a new BBC series which explores one of the most powerful forces on earth mdash the tide.Tide, which starts on BBC Northern Ireland this Sunday, will take viewers on an epic journey across four continents.The programme looks at the worldrsquos strongest and highest tides, raging whirlpools and the worldrsquos oldest tide mill mdash dating from  AD mdash which was discovered at Mahee Island on Strangford Lough.Throughout this three-part series, oceanographers, scientists and surfers share their own unique experiences and examine the impact the tide has on coastal areas.During autumn more than  per cent of the worldrsquos population of light-bellied Brent geese make the long journey from Canada to Strangford Lough.Dr Alex Portig and bird watcher Graham McElwaine explain why Brent geese make this journey across the Atlantic Ocean and how their movements are influenced by the tide.Dr Portig says: ldquoI grew up on the lough and I have been used to seeing Brent geese all my le.ldquoIt is lovely to see every autumn, geese arriving, feeding and chatting away to each other. It is definitely an iconic part of the lough.In the late s, maritime archaeologist Thomas McErlean and a team from Ulster University stumbled upon the worldrsquos earliest known tide mill during an excavation at Strangford Lough.Discovered close to the remains of Nendrum Monastery on Mahee Island, Thomas recalls the signicance of unearthing this medieval tide mill.Thomas says: ldquoThis was a site we got so excited about, we knew we were changing the course of Irish archaeology and indeedhellip industrial archaeology. We were breaking new ground and it was absolutely wonderful.In recent times, Strangford Lough has become an important site for tidal energy research and in  the worldrsquos first commercial tidal turbine was built near Portaferry.The turbine is now being decommissioned and local marine expert Simon Rogers, who is working on the removal, reveals the impact the tide has on operations. Tide is a co-production made for BBC Northern Ireland, BBC Alba, SC, TG and Sky Vision..prettyPhoto

title: Delight at fishing retreat for ex veterans
story: AN ex-army amputee who has opened a fishing retreat near Clough for disabled serviceveterans says his gamble has paid off.Robert Maxwell, who lost his right forearm and suffered severe head injuries in a serious road accident in , has been overwhelmed by support since the facility opened last week.Robert is the founder of the charity Letrsquos Do Veterans Support. Based on a five acre site at Kennedyrsquos Lake, the retreat has been visited by disabled groups who abide by the ethos of lsquofishing for funrsquo.No lead weights or barbs are allowed. Once a fish is caught and photographed it is released back into the lake.Robert explains that with the help of his close aide and fellow veteran, Nigel Cree, who is a director of Letrsquos Do Veterans Support, the net has been widened and that an invitation is being extended to anyone within the local community who wants to try out fishing.While battling to overcome his disability, Robert discovered there was little or no help for disabled veterans available in his community.Facing an interminable series of bad news on his journey to recovery he viewed the opportunity to be given a role in the British Limbless Ex-Servicemenrsquos Association as his saving grace.Robert said: ldquoWhen I got involved I saw people much worse off than myself. Some veterans had catastrophic injuries. I began to gain qualications in helping other people in the same situation as me. This helped me with my own recovery and give me a focus.ldquoMy house is down by the lake. One evening I was sitting observing how peaceful it was and it got me thinking about how I could put the lake to good use. In hindsight, the idea saved me from myself.ldquoI got a small team involved and before we knew it we had been successful in attracting funding to construct a car park, create fishing stands and a foot bridge, stock the lake with indigenous course fish and install an eco-toilet with disabled access.ldquoThere was no stopping half way through and the gamble has paid off with a successful opening and an encouraging demand for bookings growing each day.Robert describes himself as ldquonot being a lsquotea and biscuits man and doesnrsquot like to stand on ceremony.He continued: ldquoI have been helped by a devoted team of helpers and I would like to pay tribute to each of them and I dedicate this achievement to them and the three other veterans I started with who gave me great encouragement.ldquoIrsquod also like to thank Alpha Concrete, Hamilton Brothers and Cunningham Stone who were exceptional in their work with memorial plaques which have been erected.Robert said he hopes to provide fishing workshops in the near future and to get more people using the retreat.He added: ldquoA lot of time and money has been invested and when strangers visit we would ask them to adhere to the rules. They can contact me to book a session and pay a minimum day fee.For more information on Clough fishing retreat and for other initiatives which Letrsquos Do Veterans Support carry out, visit www.letsdoevents.info or contact Robert on  ..prettyPhoto

title: Event marking Men’s Health Week
story: THE St Patrick Centre in Downpatrick is hosting a special event next month to mark Menrsquos Health Week.Between June  and June , the centre dedicated to Irelandrsquos patron saint will feature an exhibition of art, craft and woodwork by members of the townrsquos Menrsquos Shed.The shedders are busily preparing for the exhibition with visitors welcome to view the work on display and learn about the work of the organisation in the community.The Menrsquos Shed aims to promote positive mental health and wellbeing to men over the age of  with the organisation offering a sizeable, well-equipped workshop at its Ballydugan Road industrial estate.There, shedders make wooden items to order such as garden seats and planters and they also produce items for community and conservation projects, like bird, bat and owl boxes for the National Trust.The Menrsquos Shed also offers opportunities for people to learn new practical skills including art, wood carving, clay, copper and leather work. The shedders also sing, cook and enjoy copious amounts of tea, biscuits and craic.And when not busy making things, the men love to get out and about visiting other Menrsquos Sheds which is a great way to network and exchange ideas.They also take part in day trips and have been involved in a new community engagement programme at Hillsborough Castle. The local shedders have also been given a fantastic tour of the grounds at Castle Ward to see their very own bird boxes being installed.The Downpatrick Menrsquos Shed is open on Tuesdays and Thursdays between .am and pm and on Friday between .am and .pm.For more information about the work of the organisation and how to get involved, telephone   or visit the Facebook Page, @MensShedDownpatrick..prettyPhoto

title: Former chairman reflects on year in office
story: FORMER Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairman Mark Murnin has described his term at the helm of the organisation as ldquoabsolutely fantastic.Mr Murnin mdash who lost his Slieve Croob seat to SDLP colleague Hugh Gallagher at the recent council election mdash served the area for four years, with his term as chairman a particular highlight.Reflecting on his year in office, which took him across Europe, the United States and the Far East, Mr Murnin said he spent almost  nights abroad and that there were many high points over the past  months.Addressing the local authorityrsquos annual meeting last week, the outgoing chairman thanked his party colleagues, fellow councillors and staff for their support.But Mr Murnin said the joy of his year in office was tinged with sadness as a number of people across the district tragically lost their lives, including a council staff member.ldquoThere were many highlights along the way, continued the chairman whose time at the helm concluded with a major charity walk which raised over pound, for Air Ambulance Northern Ireland, Harmony Community Trust and Newry Gateway Club.ldquoIt was great to start off my year with the districtrsquos special olympians and to be with them again near the end of my term in office. They represented the district so well at Irish level and again at world level in Abu Dhabi, bringing home medals.Mr Murnin also referred to the success of the inaugural Be Active Cup involving soccer teams from opposite sides of the council area. He instigated the tournament and hopes his successors will continue with it.He continued: ldquoDuring my year we had the opportunity to salute Dermot Curran, one of our long standing councillors mdash in fact the longest serving in Northern Ireland mdash with whom we enjoyed a fantastic night.ldquoIt was also a pleasure to lead our St Patrickrsquos Day parade in my home area which was really special for me. We then had the Innovation Nation event, bringing many young people from our schools together to see the exciting advances in the business opportunities that are presented to them going forward.Mr Murnin said he was also involved in helping fundraise for brave Bessbrook girl Ellen Treanor and six-year Alfie Pentony from Newry who will both travel to the US for pioneering health treatment.Sadly for the former chairman, rain intervened last August and the annual Festival of Flight international air show in Newcastle was cancelled.On a serious note, he told those in the chamber that a great responsibility comes with being a councillor.ldquoAs you strive to make this district the number one place to do business and set up a home, itrsquos worth remembering that those across the council chamber are not necessarily the enemy mdash you all must work together for the betterment of our district, he said.ldquoDuring my recent visit to New York, I was able to see how investors view the world and it was interesting to see where they see opportunities and risks, in particular.ldquoOne of those was climate risk and the importance of it, with businesses looking at it from an investors point of view. As a district, this is something that we need to take seriously, and not necessarily just rising sea levels.Mr Murnin believes that increased rainfall is going to make a dramatic dference to the way buildings and roads are designed, also highlighting the need to look at alternative energy forms.He added: ldquoBuilding for the future and how a modern city should look like will also be important. One thing that struck me looking out from the observation tower at the One World Center in New York was that the city is surprisingly green as so many of the buildings have roof top gardens and trees. This is something we should look to replicate where we can..prettyPhoto

title: Foster sisters and Alex shine at schools’ event
story: THE Newry Mourne and Down Primary Schoolsrsquo Cross Country Championships were held in Kilbroney Forest Park last Tuesday.Jodi Foster was first in the P girls and her sister Kari was second in the P girls. Although both are EDAC athletes, they were representing Spa Primary on the day.Alex Robinson battled his way to sixth in his race with the top six in each race getting a medal. There was a huge turnout of over  runners and plenty of excitement for both athletes and spectators.Bann k and fun runWednesday proved something of a Murrayrsquos benefit day out as they participated with distinction in the Bann k and Fun Run in Banbridge.Dee was seventh overall out of  runners in the k. His time was . and good enough to win first prize in the over  category. Seamus Savage, again opting for a midweek race, also took part and posted . for th place and although Janine Murray wasnrsquot overly pleased with her time of ., which was slower than in the Les Jones k on the previous Friday night, she canrsquot be accused of slacking as she turned out for the Hill and Dale the next night.The secret of course, Janine, is not to always look to better your previous time, take them in your stride and the good times will come. Not everyone can race to their max all the time.However it was Dee and Janinersquos ever-improving and dedicated son Mackenzie who deserves top billing this week as he won the k run, crossing the line well clear in a field of  runners. With a gap of almost a minute over second place, he literally showed a clean pair of heels to everyone. Well done, Mackenzie.Hill and DaleGavin Hynds was once again the first of the East Down runners to finish the Moughanmoreround of the Hill and Dale Series on Thursday night, endorsing the thought that experience is a valuable asset, as he improved his place from last yearrsquos rd to th overall. That is positively the last reference regarding birthdays and age .Niall Gibney was next, maintaining his good form in the mountains, in th place, followed by Paddy McDonald and Janine Murray, who was making her second appearance in as many nights, following on from her k efforts in Banbridge on Wednesday, and Patricia Galloway the only other female member of EDAC to turn out.Newry half marathonMarguerite Robinson ended up being the sole representative of EDAC at Newry City Half Marathon on Sunday.After a damp, chilly start the temperature eventually rose to a more comfortable level. The out and back course went from Newry past Narrow Water Castle with a bit of a detour around an industrial estate to make up the distance.Marguerite was hampered by stomach cramps and was forced to battle just to complete the course as she was loath toout.The head wind on thetrip was an added burden, but she survived the mental and physical battle and recorded a time of ., and admitted she was just pleased to be finished. Well done to her.The race was won by the remarkable Tommy Hughes mdash the Marrakesh Express mdash now aged , in .., nearly two minutes ahead of the second-placed runner. Tommy seems to break records for runners in his age category with astonishing regularityNeil in good formNeil McCartan ran in the British Milers Meet in Manchester at the weekend, recording .. in his first ,m of the season. A good, solid run. He will now set his sights on the ,m at the NI  Ulster Championships at Mary Peters Track on June .Full steam aheadTrack racing dominates the weekends for the month of June with the NIUlster Championships spread over two weekends, according to age groups. The NIUlster Childrenrsquos Games are on this weekend as well as the Irish Schools. Good luck to all who are competing. For the others there is a raft of local and not so local events mdash details available at https:athleticsni.org FixturesGet out and get running..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C May 29%2C 1979
story: BALLYKINLAR mdash The future of a pound, racehorse owned by an Ardglass hotelier is hanging in the balance after a mysterious shooting incident near Ballykinlar army camp at the weekend.The horse, Northern Luck, is awaiting an operation to remove a bullet from its neck and until the tricky surgery is carried out its owner, Mr Sean Treacey, will not knowit will be able to race again.The incident happened as Mr Treacey was training his horse on Saturday. His young  year-old jockey, Sean Armitage, was giving the horse a work-out gallop in preparation for the Sligo race meeting when he suddenly felt the horse jerk.Moments later they saw blood trickling down the neck of the horse and after finding a small hole they realised that a bullet had done the damage. The incident happened near the army camp.Mr Treacey, who lives at Ardglass Castle, reported the incident to police and investigations began immediately. However, they have not discovered who fired the bullet.ldquoThe future of the horse is very much in the balance, said an unhappy Mr Treacey. ldquoThe bullet is lodged close to the horsersquos spine and my vet has suggested a very tricky operation is needed to remove it.ldquoWorse still, it could easily have been my jockey who was hit. He was in the racing position on the horse and had the bullet been six inches higher it would have hit him in the head.A police spokesman confirmed the incident and said that it had been established that the horse had gunshot wounds, possibly from a . bullet.ldquoOur investigations are continuing and we hope to be in a position to establish whether it could have been a ricochet or a stray bullet from the firing range, or a deliberate shooting incident, he said.LEITRIM mdash Road racer Tom Herron, tragically killed at the North West meeting on Saturday, was buried beside Leitrim Presbyterian Church on Monday. The mourners included many of his racing colleagues, who had flown from the Isle of Man to be at the graveside.The funeral service was conducted by the Rev James Johnston, who referred to Herronrsquos many qualities and the determination which had taken him to the top.Herron was the third motorcycle ace from mid Down to die in race accidents. The brilliant Killyleagh rider Brian Steenson and the up and coming Ballynahinch rider Brian McCombe were both killed in accidents at the Isle of Man TT.DOWNPATRICK mdash St Patrickrsquos Festival has the potential to become one of the most important and spectacular of its kind in Northern Ireland. That was the firm message this week from one of the men who spearheaded the highly successful four-day event in Downpatrick.Mr Frank Connolly said the amazing reaction from the public and the dedication of the -strong organising committee left no doubt in his mind that the festival was capable of becoming a crowd-pulling annual attraction.ldquoI believe strongly that this festival has laid down a tremendous  for us to build on for the future, he said. ldquoI would like to see it become the leading festival in Northern Ireland and there is no reason why this should not be the case.ldquoIt was unbelievable to see so many people enjoying themselves, young and old. The spirit is definitely there and local people can increase the size of the festival each year and have something to be proud of.The festival was given a firm nod of approval by Mr Eddie McGrady, chairman of Down Council.He said the event had been a tremendous success and showed clearly that the way is open for an extended and even more ambitious festival in years to follow.ldquoThis festival has shown what a small number of dedicated people can do. On behalf of myself and the people of Down District I would like to thank the organisers for producing an event for Downpatrick which everyone can be proud of, he added.BALLYGOWAN mdash More than  employees at the Belfast Ropeworks in Ballygowan, who walked out at the weekend in support of a pay claim, have ed to work.The men, all sht workers, downed tools on Thursday in protest over a productivity bonus offered by the management. However, the dispute has been settled and the firm, situated on the Moss Road, is operating as normal.A company spokesman said: ldquoThe men have accepted the offer and have all ed to work. Fortunately, the action only lasted for a limited period.PORTAFERRY mdash Declan Mackell sailed single-handed out of Portaferry on Sunday afternoon to go round the world. A handful of boats accompanied him out of Strangford Lough after he had enjoyed lunch at the Portaferry Hotel.ldquoYes, Irsquom probably mad, he admitted before he left. ldquoBut I see this outing as something that should satisfy my curiosity in the same way as my transatlantic trip last year.His -foot yacht dipped gently into the Irish Sea as the former carpenter tacked his way out of sight and got his self-steering gear into action for his first night at sea.Declan, who has prepared his boat over the last six months, will take in France, the Mediterranean, the Canaries, Atlantic and Pacic Oceans, Australia, New Zealand, Indian Ocean and Cape Hope before coming back to Portaferry.CASTLEWELLAN mdash Castlewellan Library, formerly the Market House, was officially opened by Mr Peter OrsquoHagen, chairman of the South Eastern Education and Library Board, this week.Almost pound, was pumped into covering the building into a library and the Board agree that the expense was worth it. They now have a site in a central position in the town, convenient to shops, bus routes and car parks.CROSSGAR mdash A new pound, for Lissara Presbyterian Church was opened and dedicated at a specialon Monday night. The extension is in memory of a former minister, the Rev Samuel Finlay, and was opened by Mrs Gladys Finlay.The Moderator of the General Assembly, the Right Rev David Burke, was the main guest. Also present were the Rev James Lamont, Moderator of Down Presbytery, and the Rev S A Matthews, church minister.M Dunlop, of Dunlop Bros, Saintfield, which carried out the extension work, presented the key to the church to Mrs Finlay, who performed the opening ceremony after which Rev Burke dedicated the extension. Following the special service the congregation were invited to the church hall for tea.STRANGFORD mdash The Department of the Environment has announced restrictions to the Strangford ferry service because of fuel shortages. The Department says the new schedule will operate ldquountil further notice.KILLOUGH mdash Members of the Killough branch of the SDLP have hit out at the delay in providing facilities for children in the village. The members say it is completely unfair that every town and village in the area has two or three play areas while Killough has none.ARDGLASS mdash It has been proposed that the new residential home for the elderly in Ardglass should be named Ardview House. The recommendation was supported recently by the Down District Executive Team of the Eastern Health and Social Services Board.SOCCER mdash Cochrane Corry Cup holders Kilmore Rec surrendered their title at Dickson Park, Downpatrick, when arch rivals Annalong Swts came back from the dead with three goals in the last  minutes to win -.Kilmore, with the Junior Shield already under their belts, looked in confident mood after taking a second minute lead and seemed to home and dry when they added a second goal midway through the second half.But Annalong, who fell in the Junior Cup final, showed their determination to avoid a second cup final defeat in the same season by coming back in an exciting last quarter to snatch a superb win..prettyPhoto

title: Mooney misses out as Down set to entertain Tipperary
story: DOWN will go into next Sundayrsquos All-Ireland SFC Qualier against Tipperary without the talismanic Caolan Mooney.The Rostrevor man picked up a red card after lsquobehaving in a way which is dangerous to an opponentrsquo, in last weekrsquos high-octane clash with Armagh at Pairc Esler.The County Board appealed against that decision and the hearing at Croke Park was held on Monday night by the Central Hearings Committee.However, after due process, they found the alleged infraction proven and Mooneyrsquos automatic one-match ban stands.This is a crushing blow for Down.Mooney has been the cornerstone of the Down side over the past few years and his swashbuckling runs from deep have been one of the few high points in recent campaigns.However, Paddy Tallyrsquos side will be strongly fancied to progress.Last Sundayrsquos heartbreaking defeat at Pairc Esler was a bitter pill to swallow for the Down players, but they must now regroup and hit the ground running against a wounded Tipperary outfit.Tipp were soundly beaten - to - by Limerick in the first round of the Munster SFC a fortnight ago and that was a severe below to manager Liam Kearnsrsquo aspirations.A few years back Tipp were regarded as one of the best young sids in Ireland, but they appear to have hit the skid pan and are now there for the taking.They narrowly missed out on promotion to Division  of the ACFL two years ago, but have fallen from grace big time and were relegated back into Division  at the end of March.They have outstanding players in Liam Casey and Steven OrsquoBrien, while rookie Daire Brennan has the potential to become a big name in the sport.Down, on the other hand, will recall their last meeting with Tipp in March of last year when Eamon Burnsrsquo side registered a - to - win at Pairc Esler in their last game of the ACFL Division  campaign.A win that day for Down was not enough to prevent them from relegation, but there have been massive changes in the Mourne team since then.It is expected that out of the  that started last March, only three players from that day are likely to begin the game against Tipperary.Meanwhile, the countyrsquos senior camogie side take on Antrim in the Ulster Championship final at Clones on Sunday.Down go into the showdown full of confidence, given, their - to - win over Derry on Saturday, despite shooting  wides.ldquoGoing forward we are going to have to address those wides, said manager Martina Rooney.ldquoBut look, I am more than happy with the attitude of the girls. They worked very hard from start to finish, maybe dipped a bit during the middle of the second half. But we finished strongly.The only period when Derry looked to have a chance was entering the last quarter when Graacuteinne McGoldrick poached a goal and then added a point to close the gap to - to -.ldquoYes, that was a hairy enough time, but when you need players to stand up, they really did. We brought in a couple of subs as well and they steadied things up, she added.ldquoWe would be happy enough with our overall effort, but there is more in us and we have enough to work on this week..prettyPhoto

title: O’Hagan swoops to conquer Derry
story: A RUTHLESSLY efficient Down side secured their place in the Ulster Championship final against Antrim at the Athletic Grounds, Armagh, on Saturday afternoon.Portaferryrsquos Niamh Mallon was prominent for Down, taking points from play and frees, but it was Clonduffrsquos Paula OrsquoHagan who came good with a goal and a point in the dying stages to halt a Derry comeback in its tracks.Derry opened the scoring with a free after just  seconds, but two unanswered points from the reliable Mallon and Castlewellanrsquos Sorcha McCartan, a member of the countyrsquos highly successful All-Ireland Minor Shield winning squad, gave her side a - to - lead after  minutes.Mairead McNicholl restored parity with a point from play before Derry seized the lead again with a point from play, but this was to be their last score of the half as Down went nap.Three points, including two from play and another from McCartan, catapulted Down into a commanding - to - lead at the interval.Down opened the second half on the front foot and two consecutive frees from Mallon extended their lead to seven points, - to -.However, Derry summoned up an heroic fightback and a goal from Grainne McGoldrick and three unanswered points left just a single point in it with seven minutes remaining.Downrsquos backs were certainly against the wall, but cometh the hour, cometh OrsquoHagan and a pointed free and then a sensational goal put daylight between the sides again with Down easing up in the closing stages to record an impressive five-point win.Down: C McGourty, N Kelly, A Savage, C McGilligan, K McMullan, D Magee, C Rocks, A McAleenan, A Keown , SL Carr, S McCartan , P Gribben , N MallonC Caldwell, F Carr . Subs: D Harrison for McAleenan, O Gribben for Mallon, K Tinnelly for McMullan, N McCullagh for McCartan.Derry: N McQuillan, C Glass, B Niacute Chaiside, S Donaghy, M Kerr, A Niacute Chaiside, Aacute McAllister, G McNicholl , D OrsquoKane, G McGoldrick , S Quinn, M McNicholl , A Quinn, S Graham, M Hegarty. Subs: T Mellon for Hegarty, A Devlin for A Niacute Chaiside, Aacute Kelly for A Quinn.Down -Derry -ULSTER CAMOGIE SEMI-FINAL.prettyPhoto

title: Political ‘state of emergency’ call
story: A DOWNPATRICK man has declared a state of emergency in Northern Ireland.Francis Morgan claims there is no one in politics to represent the ldquovoice of the people and is encouraging residents across the province to take part in what he is describing as a ldquoday of silent solidarity on June .Mr Morgansaid that in the absence of a Stormont administration, someone needs to do something to bring about change and tackle the ldquoworrying issue of climate change.Explaining that his declaration is borne out of frustration at the current political stagnation, he said he has no confidence in politicians mdash particularly those in Sinn Fein and the DUP mdash to bring about the change people he believes are demanding.ldquoI have declared a state of emergency because no one  is prepared to do it, said Mr Morgan. ldquoI am hearing with increasing regularity peoplersquos concern about the current political impasse. Out of the  people I asked, only one felt they were being represented at Stormont.ldquoI have decided to speak out and am working with others on my campaign. Rather than talk about doing something, I am going down this road because I believe that action is stronger than words.Mr Morgan says he is attempting to ascertainthere is consensus among the people of Northern Ireland for political change and politicians who want to work together for everyonersquos benefit.ldquoI am throwing my idea out there for people to stop what they are doing on June  between pm and .pm to show their frustration at what is currently happening, he explained. ldquoPolitical stagnation and climate change are crucial issues that we must do something about.ldquoI hope that people in every town, village and hamlet across this district and throughout Northern Ireland, including post-primary school students and those who attend further education colleges and universities, will take part.Mr Morgan said he wants residents and those who work in shops and offices to demonstrate that they want change.ldquoJune  is an opportunity for people to demand change, equal rights and equality. Together we can make this happen. I want people to select a venue in their own area and meet there in silence for just a short period to send out a clear message that they have had enough and are demanding change, he continued.ldquoI am particularly keen to see students taking part as they are the future. We need to listen to what they have to say, particularly with regard to the future of local politics and the planet. We have not had a government in this country for two years which is disgraceful. I believe that our MLAs have effectively disqualied themselves from public office.He argued Northern Ireland, which was once a world leader in many fields, particularly engineering, needed a system of government which was not run along ldquoorange and green lines.He continued: ldquoWe want our country to be a world leader again, this time in agreeing political solutions and addressing the issue of climate change. I believe that we need a system of government which is based on non-party politics.ldquoParty politics across the globe has failed and in all my  years I have never had a government that represented me or indeed one that I had respect for. This has to end. We need a government for everyone which comprises independent members bringing their own particular strengths to the table.ldquoThere is no point calling for change and standing back. We have to make this happen with human rights and equality for everyone, regardless of their religion, political view, sexual preferences or colour of their skin. We need government by the people for the people.He added: ldquoI hope people will grasp the opportunity they are being offered on June . This is not a protest, but an opportunity for people to demonstrate silently that they have had enough.ldquoI encourage people to stand alongside me and others to make that happen. More details will follow on social media in the run-up to June ..prettyPhoto

title: Prince of Wales pays visit to Finnebrogue Artisan plant
story: THE Prince of Wales visited Downpatrick meat producer Finnebrogue Artisan last week mdash yet managed not to taste its market leading nitrate-free bacon.Instead the first-in-line to the throne made do with a cup of tea at the processing plant in Down Industrial Estate on Wednesday, despite being enticed by the waft of cooked bacon and sausages.Prince Charles had specically asked to visit Finnebrogue as part of his two-day trip to Northern Ireland last Tuesday and Wednesday.A long-term environmentalist who runs his own farm, the prince is very interested and supportive of sustainable farming practices and food processing techniques.Finnebroguersquos chairman, Denis Lynn, later told the Recorder that the princersquos visit ldquowas very relaxed and that he was very natural and knowledgeable.ldquoI suppose it was a meeting of like minds as we are both interested in the same things. It was a honour to show him around Finnebrogue and what we do. ldquoHe was very interested and asked all the right questions.Prince Charles arrived at Finnebrogue around .pm after he and his we, the Duchess of Cornwall, had visited the poundm Grand Central Hotel in Belfast.The royal couple chatted with Lady Joy Hastings, who lives near Killyleagh. She is the widow of the late Sir William Hastings, founder of the family-run Hastings Hotels group.At Finnebrogue Artisan, Prince Charles, who was not accompanied by the Duchess, was greeted by the Lord Lieutenant of Co Down, Mr David Lindsay, the High Sherf of Co Down, Mr Harry Shields, Mr Lynn and his we, Christine.Also in attendance were Cllr Terry Andrews, deputy chairman of Newry, Mourne and Down Council, and Mr Liam Hannaway, the councilrsquos chief executive.The prince was told in a boardroom meeting how Finnebrogue launched the first nitrate-free bacon in  before he got sight ndash and smell ndash of freshly cooked sausages and bacon from the companyrsquos range.As members of Finnebroguersquos product development team cooked in the kitchen, Prince Charles said: ldquoTherersquos a great smell of bacon here.Mr Lynn showed the prince how Finnebrogue was soon going to be introducing a cardboard alternative to the black plastic food tray for its sausages mdash which received a royal nod of approval.Mr Lynn described a fruit extract used in the bacon production instead of nitrates or other additives as ldquomagic dust to the prince.The prince moved on to view Finnebroguersquos production of sausages from a viewing corridor and was shown how one million sausages were produced and packaged each day by workers and robots on the production line.Operations manager Chris Duke, from Killyleagh, explained the origins of Finnebrogue and Mr Lynnrsquos determination to produce the best quality of meat, with the help of a visual timeline.The prince then moved into the staff canteen where he chatted with members of Mr Lynnrsquos family and members of staff, including product development team member Sarah Savage from Downpatrick.Before a hamper of Finnebrogue foods were presented to the prince, Mr Lynn told him: ldquoThe last time we met was  years ago in Belfast. We were a small artisan business, our turnover was about pound million.ldquoEleven years and two days later we are still a small artisan business doing exactly the same thing, but we have just got a bit bigger.ldquoThank you so much for coming, I have really appreciated it, I have really had a great time talking to you about your understanding of the environment. I think we are really together on this.Mr Lynn could not resist joking with Prince Charles that Finnebrogue bacon and sausages were ldquobetter than the princersquos own Duchy range, to which Charles good-naturedly replied to other guests present: ldquoHersquos longing to say that..prettyPhoto

title: Programme for children with disabilities
story: A NEW project aimed at getting children with disabilities involved in sport has been launched in Downpatrick.The Wheelie Active Club, which is underway at Down Leisure Centre, is part of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Everybody Active EBA programme.The club, which is aimed at promoting the development of Disability Sport throughout the district, is intended for children aged - with physical disabilities.The project aims to give children with physical disabilities opportunities to develop physical literacy and movement skills for sport in a range of safe, progressive and inclusive activities.Friends and siblings are also encouraged to take part in the activities with the understanding that safety and enjoyment is key to the ethos of the programme.Council chairman Charlie Casey said: ldquoThis is a fantastic programme and I am pleased to see such opportunities for young children to encourage them to be active.ldquoWe are delighted to be able to provide facilities and activities for young children who usually donrsquot have as many opportunities to participate in sport.ldquoThis new programme will provide activities for everyone to improve their health and wellbeing.Downpatrick Wheelie Active Club runs on Tuesday evenings from pm to pm..prettyPhoto

title: Pupils in the spotlight for online TV channel
story: PUPILS from Christ the King Primary School in Drumaness became television stars for the day recently.The children were chosen to take part in an online programme produced by the Education Authorityrsquos EATV.CK NewsDesk, the governmentrsquos ICT digital  for schools, chose the schoolrsquos P class taught by Miss Lindsey Upritchard as an example of excellent teaching and use of NewsDesk within the classroom.CK NewsDesk is a digital resource which is freely available to all teachers and pupils in Northern Ireland with a CK account.Some pupils, including Ciara Fagan, were interviewed by the EATV team about how they use the resource.The EATV clip will be used to help other schools and teachers see the benefits of using Newsdesk within the classroom mdash putting Christ the King on the digital map for schools in Northern Ireland.NewsDesk provides pupils with an opportunity to engage with current news stories in a digital environment, in turn producing their own news and stories which are important to them.NewsDesk also provides pupils with an opportunity to practice talking and listening, reading and writing skills that have been previously taught in the classroom..prettyPhoto

title: Short term financial reprieve for playgroup
story: EDUCATION chiefs have been urged to provide ring-fenced funding for playgroups across the district to allow them to plan for the future with confidence.The appeal comes after the Tiny Toons playgroup based in Bishopscourt, outside Downpatrick, secured vital interim funding to help pay staff wages over the summer, just weeks after a previous bid for much-needed finance proved unsuccessful.The playgroup has secured finance under the Department of Educationrsquos strategic support fund after it failed to secure money under the Departmentrsquos Pathway Fund, which is administered by the Early Years Partnership.Those who run playgroups in rural areas say they deliver the same curriculum as those based in towns, but seem to suffer most when it comes to funding allocations.Applications to the highly competitive Pathway funding stream are subject to review by an independent . Those that are successful are provided with financial support for one year only.It is a system that the chairwoman of the Bishopscourtrsquos playgroup is keen to see changed.Mrs Patricia Curran, who revealed that Tiny Toons recently missed out on Pathway funding by a narrow margin, said playgroups did a ldquomagnicent job, particularly in rural area where working parents rely heavily upon them.She said playgroups look after children at the most critical time in their development and need to be provided with financial certainty.A number of playgroups across the district revealed recently that they were organising additional fundraising activities to generate income and were appealing for donations of everyday essentials including toilet paper, wipes, photocopying paper and even bin bags.Mrs Curran revealed that Tiny Toons only found out about the strategic support fund by chance and while pleased the cash will pay staff wages over the summer, fresh funding applications will have to be made at the start of next year to cover costs.ldquoWhile we narrowly missed out on Pathway funding, we have secured other support from a fund which we knew nothing about, she continued.ldquoThe money we have secured will keep us ticking over. We are not saying everything is hunky dory as a result of this particular finance. We have money to pay for  childrenrsquos places from next September which is good. The money secured under the strategic support fund will pay our staff over July and August.Mrs Curran said that had the playgroup not been made aware of the strategic fund it would have been a ldquovery dferent story.ldquoWhile securing funding comes as a relief, it does not provide us with any degree of certainty. We will have to make a fresh application for Pathway funding at the start of next year and go through this process all over again, as we and others do every year, she continued.Mrs Curran said Tiny Toons and other playgroups across the district were operating in a ldquochallenging financial climate.ldquoThe provision of ring-fenced funding is vital for us, she declared. ldquoWhile things are fine for now, we know that come the New Year we will have to start filling in funding application forms again.ldquoRing-fenced funding for a two or three-year period would provide certainty and help playgroups operate in a climate where there would not be a cloud hanging over them.ldquoThe funding issue affects all those in the education sector and I read recently that one headmaster warned that his school could be forced to only open four days a week as it did not have enough money.Mrs Curran said that while strategic support funding has provided Tiny Toons with short term relief, guaranteed ring-fenced financial support would provide certainly and allow future planning.She added: ldquoGiven the current funding model, there is always uncertainty hanging over us. We are voluntary workers and we should not have this pressure on our heads. That said,we did not do this work, who  is going to do it ldquoNot many people want to do voluntary work any more because of the pressure involved. We in Bishopscourt were worried about paying our staff and have been provided with some relief. We are also grateful to our parents for their continued support and loyalty.The Bishopscourt playgroup will be taking part in a sponsored bag pack at the Asda supermarket in Downpatrick this Saturday between am and pm. Volunteers are welcome to get involved..prettyPhoto

title: There’s no way Lynch can lose
story: DONARD, Commedagh, Bernagh, Binnian mdash everyone knowrsquos them, the higher peaks in the beautul mountain range that is the Mournes mdash a place that all who hail from south east Down are proud to call home.There are loads more minors peaks and hillocks in the  square miles that are great fun to explore and after decades of Hill  Dales the lsquoBroken Wing Commanderrsquo decided last winter that he would dream up a new route for one of the  series.First there was the venue mdash Meelmore Lodge. If you havenrsquot been to Meelmore Lodge lately, then go check it out. A signicant amount of investment has been done there and therersquos great parking facilities and easy access to the Ulster Way under the shadow of Meelmore .Therersquos accommodation there, including pods and plenty of camping spaces - great for a night out. The race exited the campsite with the organisers issuing strict instructions for runners not to cross walls or fences, except through an open gate where a marshal would be there to direct them.Wet tops were the order of the day, for while it was mild and dry, but there were a few ominous grey clouds around and once up near to , feet the climate conditions can be much more challenging.By the way, one of the race directorsdecided it would be wise to recce the course earlier in the week.So on Monday evening meeting at the above-mentioned stunning Meelmore Lodge, he gathered with a few so-called running mates. They set off, quickly deciding to start the race on the green paddock below the lodge .The decision to start there had far-reaching consequences for just adjacent to the chosen start location, come Thursday at pm, a camping couple decided to cook dinner on a makesht stove - they must have been planning a quiet romantic evening with stunning views and just as they had sat down, Frank Morgan, the perennial starterwith his flags and tape followed soon after by hundreds of runners and spectators gathering beside them - no need for them to put on the TV, they had all the live entertainment they needed.Back to Monday evening and the lsquocourse recce crewrsquo followed the Trassey river, crossing it before the hard climb up Slievenaglough, then following the green shoot up to the first check point at its summit.Then it was the technical descent down and up to the summit of lesser-known Lukersquos Mountain and from there making their way home.Mountain leader and rescue stalwart, Ian McCracken fell not once, but twice going over on his ankle badly mdash thankfully, no need for the mountain rescue as the lsquoProphetrsquo was there to guide him home safely mdash poor Ian, after all the winter preparation there would be no Thursday evening race for him.As the runners milled around , Pete Grant, who was surprisingly wearing his club vest for a change, must have had a category win on his mind, as he moaned and groaned about the long, sharp start, delaying the time before he could get his shoes properly mucky.Later on, however, that would be the least of his worries as for some reason he decided to leave his car keys somewhere out on the open mountain at a grid reference that to the present time only God knows.As Frankrsquos whistle was blown at ::the  runners charged off up the track and onto the open mountain.The route, mostly on sheep paths, took them directly onto the craggy summit of Slievenaglough that is part of the Mourne Wall route - a mountain that meant something on Thursday evening rather than just being an anonymous part of the route from the Harersquos Gap to Commedagh.Positively, pretty much everyone successfully reached the cut-off point of  minutes for the first mile that included around  feet of climbing.Newcastle ACrsquos Seamy Lynch had established a comfortable lead early in the race, clear of his club mate Mark Stephens with Newry ACrsquos Esther Dickson also comfortable in the womanrsquos race, ahead of Karen Wilton from Lisburn and Mourne runner Sarah Graham.It should have been plain sailing for everyone, but as often happens, the low cloud rolled in onto the ridge between Slievenaglough and Lukersquos and the summit of Lukersquos disappeared from view. We are still not sure that everyone made it there, but what is certain is that everyone made it back.Legal counsel Higgins lives le in the fast lane, balancing defending the indefensible in one court room or another with le on the farm and a Viking love nest in Tullybrannigan.If therersquos controversy in a sport not known for its controversy, Higgins perhaps will not be too far away - gamekeeper turned poacher  On the way home he chose his own line and clearly there had been some pillow talk, for she did too - slightly dferent, but both probably crossed the moral line, but probably not far enough to be eligible for a criminal conviction.His talk of bringing his finely honed orienteering skills to the table was not convincing the lsquoBroken Wing Commanderrsquo, but despite his protests supported strongly by the lsquoHenrsquo, the directors have no appetite for years in court ending in the European Court of Justice, no doubt, so the results stand.A fine run from Ballydrain junior Jared Martin to come home in third - a big star for the future  Many of the runners remarked this was the best HD course in years and it was great to freshen the series up with a new route - food for thought for the organisers for  Many thanks to all at Meelmore Lodge for the use of their facilities in this beautul location, the marshals, time keepers and people behind the scenes who keep the series running smoothly each week.Thanks also to the Avoca Hotel  Spa on their excellent food and beverages, by order of Jack OrsquoHare.Tomorrow night sees theto Millstone with full body cover required. Registration is at OrsquoHarersquos Lounge Bars, Donard Park, Newcastle from pm. Race starts at .pm sharp..prettyPhoto

title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. Businesswoman and fashionista Shirley“We’ve seen a few clips but we don’t get to see the whole episodes until the public sees them.”While it’s been billed as Northern Ireland’s equivalent as TOWIE and Made In Cha the characters come across as being a lot more down to earth.Ruth, , said: “It’s just the way we are everyday. After a while, after the second or third time, you do forget the cameras are there.” Ruth explained how she got involved with the programme which was filmed at the start of last summer: “They went to my friend’s salon and they were giving out flyers trying to find someone who comes from a farming background and is also into the beauty and all. Helen said about me and passed on my details. They contacted me and I said I’d be interested, it sounds like great craic.”Ruth revealed that it wasn’t technically her TV debut: “When I was in primary school I was in school choir of the year, but that was in a choir and I’m a blur.”In one scene, Ruth who is a member of a gun club takes two of her friends shooting: “Hollie had shot once before, Helen had never shot in her le. Cue her dad John: “When I was training as a beautician I had to practice eyebrow waxing. I got my kit and asked dad would he let me practice. I think I got one strip pulled off and he stopped me. He said he’d been in enough accidents on the farm but that was by the far the worst. He ended up with one bushy eyebrow and one normal one.”She added: “My oldest brother John is a full time farmer. He’s won’t be on the show, he’s a bit shy. He works on the farm with my dad and my dad’s friend Billy.“My mumhelps out on the farm before her own job as a classroom assistant in a special needs school.”Ruth appears in the show alongside her brother Neil. As a duo they’re used to being in the limelight together.She said: “Neil’s a country singer. We used to sing together. We were a two-piece band then I went to Australia for a year and he went out on his own.“He started to make it really well on his own so I left him to it. I started a new job as a beautician and helped my dad out on the farm.”So has she got the bitten by the TV bug “It’s was really good craic,” she said. “If there was a second series and they asked me to be in it, I’d definitely say yes. If this is the first time you have subscribed to emails from JPIMedia Ltd, the publishers of Belfast News Letter, please check your inbox to very your email address.  .html.valAn attempt to #restore the relationship# between the Presbyterian Church and its mother church in Scotland has been rejected by the General Assembly.The South Belfast Presbytery had put forward a memorial at this afternoon’s General Assembly which proposed further debate on the decision taken last year to exclude the Church of Scotland moderator from the General Assembly based largely on dferences on same-sex relationships.The notice of motion to debate the decision at the General Assembly in  was defeated by  votes to . Presenting the memorial Morris Gault, Minister of Cooke Centenary, said: “For many of us the Church of Scotland being our mother church, means that they are family. The decision that we made last year, was to say that the moderator of our mother church was not welcome at our assembly anymore. That part of our family was not welcome in our house.”.ev-modals .modal.in .modal-dialog He added: “I found it dficult to understand last year, that having watched the Scottish moderator leave our assembly obviously heart broken, that we immediately passed a resolution that said that the councils, committees and departments of our church could collaborate with the Church of Scotland for the mutual benefit of both. Such meetings have been taking place. So what was the point in passing the earlier resolution ”Seconding the motion, former clerk of South Belfast Cecil Graham, said: “Our focus is on the restoration of relationships which go back over many centuries. Indeed the Scottish Kirk is regarded as our mother church.“As in most families there can at times be tensions and disagreements but pastoral experience evidence suggests that the restoration of relations brings healing. The heart of this memorial is the restoration of this relationship with the Church of Scotland.”Opposing the memorial Rev Jonathan Boyd, minister of Hyde Park and Lylehill Church in Templepatrick, said it was “time to move on”.He said: “It’s been six years since I was ordained and I can’t remember a General Assembly where we haven’t debated these issues.“I don’t see how it does our denomination any good to keep revisiting an idea that is so clearly being rejected in not one, not two, not three, but four successive votes. Surely not even Theresa May wouldn’t go so far as to put the same issue to a fth vote.”He said: “I pray that there will be such revival and reform in the church of Scotland that we will be unanimous in wanting to restore these symbolic links, but that time hasn’t come.”Following the defeat of the memorial Clerk of the General Assembly Trevor Gribben said: “Democracy is one of the strengths and hallmarks of our Presbyterianism and system of church government – debating together, in General Assembly, in an open and transparent way. “I am sure that there will be some in our church who will be title: removal of penarth lampposts prompts creation of art works
story: Vaughan Gething fighting the lamp post campaign with Haf Weightonand Gltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtemma Crutchley lt spangtlt spangtlt spangt" Artworks created over the removal of town lamppostsHaf Weighton is fighting to save the lampposts with the use of her art" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentAN artist has created a body of work in response to the removal of Penarthrsquos Victorian lampposts.Lampposts across Penarth are being replaced with modern LED lighting, as the Penarth Times has previously reported.But campaigners have asked that the old posts be left in place to preserve Penarthrsquos heritage, with new ones installed beside.Haf Weighton is a textile artist based in Penarth, and she spoke of her ldquoshock when she heard of the council plans.Ms Weighton said: ldquo I decided to create interpretations of each building on the Esplanade with the lamp posts in each one.ldquoI stitched the names of the streets that will lose their posts around the edges of each piece of art.ldquoIn some ways I was trying to give our heritage an opportunity to live on.Ms Weighton has created six pieces which are on show at an exhibition at Penarth Pier Pavilion.Gemma Crutchley, who founded a petition to save the lampposts, said: ldquoI feel itrsquos important for these symbols of the Welsh industrial heritage to be kept on our streets. I want my children to grow up knowing and seeing their local history around them.Cardf South and Penarth AM Vaughan Gething met with Ms Weighton and Ms Crutchley over the campaign recently .Mike Clogg, the Vale of Glamorgan Council operational manager for neighbourhood services and transport, said: ldquoThe council is replacing a number of lighting columns in ious areas of Penarth. There are electrical and structural safety issues with some of the older posts and it would not be practicable or cost-effective to attempt repairs. Others will be converted to fit LED lights in line with the energy reduction strategy. This is better for the environment as LED lights produce less CO.ldquoIt is dficultnot impossible to find parts for the old Victorian lamp posts, so retention and refurbishment of the street lights is generally not an option.ldquoThe lantern design on the posts is also incompatible with a conversion to LED lighting and the switch forms part of the councilrsquos Street Lighting Energy Reduction Strategy.Ms Weightonrsquos pavilion exhibition, called lsquoAdre ndash Homersquo continues until May .The petition can be found at www.change.org p vale-of-glamorgan-council-save-the-victorian-heritage-of-penarth. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: penarth resident named wales green party mep candidate
story: Anthony Slaughter, the current leader of the party in Wales, has been involved in politics for more than a decade, both in and around Cardf and across Wales.Mr Slaughter previously served two terms as the Welsh Greenrsquos deputy leader and represented them in parliamentary, Welsh Assembly and local authority elections.The EU Parliament elections run from May  to .Mr Slaughter, who has lived in Penarth for the last  years, working as a garden designer, said: ldquoI am proud and excited to have this opportunity to represent Wales Green Party in the European elections in May.ldquoWe have always been committed to remaining in the EU and consistently supported a Peoplersquos Vote on any Brexit deal. We stand unequivocally for freedom of movement ndash Penarth, with its reliance on tourism, would otherwise be affected directly.ldquoA vote for the Greens in this election is also a vote for the only party that truly recognises the priority for bold action on the accelerating climate emergency and the need for transformation of our profoundly unequal society.ldquoThe Greens are the only group prioritising the need to face environmental challenges and crises. We need cooperation on an international level to address this issue.ldquoPenarth is also well placed to take advantage of our initiatives - Green power like a tidal lagoon would be a huge boon to the area.Mr Slaughter also said he is proud of his long-running engagement with community environmental group Gwyrddio Penarth Greening.His involvement includes establishing a community orchard, a local food festival and promoting sustainable public transport.On a national level Mr Slaughter has been involved with a range of activist groups and campaigns including Extinction Rebellion, the Peoplersquos Assembly, and rsquos Plenty for Wales. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. enough money to refurbish the hospicersquos complementary therapy room and presented the charity with a lsquoCuddleBlanketrsquo, a special piece of equipment that keeps the childrsquos temperature low hearts that can be placed in the childrsquos hand or blanket when saying goodbye, while the parents keep the accompanying keyring as a reminder of the connection shared.Mr Williams said: ldquoWe something we never got to do.Mrs Williams said: ldquoEvery time we come into T# Hafan itrsquos amazing mdash the staff at the hospice have provided so much support for us as a family.ldquoOur three children have grown up here too and have had the pleasure of meeting other children in similar situations which has helped them enormously.ldquoWe canrsquot thank our friends, family and the community enough for their dedication in helping us raise the money to comfort bereaved families and to keep Elisrsquo memory alive.ldquoIt wouldrsquove been Elisrsquo th birthday last October so we wanted to title: vale council leader cllr john thomas is ousted as head of the authority
story: Vale of Glamorgan Conservatives have told Cllr Thomas they no longer want him to lead the authority following their annual general meeting on Monday, April , sources have said.Barry Dyfan-ward councillor Vincent Bailey is the Conservativesrsquo choice to take over the leadership of the council this month, The Local Democracy Reporting Service has been told.In order for a leadership change to happen, either Cllr Thomas would have to resign or he would have to lose a motion of no confidence. A no confidence motion would have to be tabled with  daysrsquo notice.It is understood the saga around the transfer of Llancarfan Primary School to Rhoose, described by many as a ldquoclosure, was a driving factor behind Conservatives calling for Cllr Thomasrsquo departure.Cllr Thomasrsquo cabinet approved the controversial move despite opposition from parents and campaigners and criticism from one cabinet member, Councillor Gordon Kemp.Cllr Kemp was eventually sacked from the cabinet after joining  Conservative councillors who abstained on voting for the administrationrsquos budget.The LDRS is also aware of ldquoserious discontent from several of Cllr Thomasrsquo backbenchers over a number of ldquoPR blunders, including proposed car parking charges throughout the Vale.Cllr Bailey, who is the current chairman of the councilrsquos environment and regeneration scrutiny committee, has been on the authority since the  after gaining the Dyfan ward in Barry for the Conservatives from Labour.Cllr Bailey said:ldquoI would firstly like to take this opportunity to pay tribute to John Thomas, who has worked exceptionally hard for the Vale of Glamorgan during his time as leader of the council and the Conservative Group.ldquoI would like to thank him for all of his help and support, I look forward to working with him and other colleagues as we move forward.ldquoThe Vale is a fantastic place, and fellow councillors and I look forward to delivering a bright and prosperous future for all our residents.ldquoIt is a huge honour to have been elected group leader, following a vote at the annual general meeting of the Conservative Group.ldquoThe council and its employees exist to serve local people, and moving forward our priorities must include delivering progress on the Dinas Powys By-Pass, revisiting decisions to introduce car parking charges and close Llancarfan School, and looking again at the options to improve transport links between the A and J of the M.Cllr Thomas was elected to represent the St Athan ward in , and has been leader of the authority since May .A Vale council spokesman said: ldquoCllr John Thomas continues to be leader of the Vale of Glamorgan CouncilldquoThere has been one change to the councilrsquos political executive. Cllr Bob Penrose has resigned from his position as cabinet member for learning and culture. This post is currently vacant. The councilrsquos cabinet remains otherwise unchanged.ldquoThe meeting of full council on May  will go ahead as planned.ldquoHowever, the resignation of two members of the Conservative group has caused the postponement of the councilrsquos annual general meeting scheduled for May .ldquoAt the AGM there is a discussion around the allocation of committee seats and chairmanships of committees. There is currently uncertainty as to how committee seats will be allocated.ldquoIt is therefore appropriate to postpone the AGM so that the council can properly plan for that meeting and so that decisions can be made based on up-to-date political calculations. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log        ,params: .push-- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: vale of glamorgan council leader sets date for departure
story: Council leader John Thomas was deposed as leader of the Vale Conservatives by Cllr Vincent Bailey following a party annual general meeting this week.Cllr Thomas, who has already said he will step down, told a full council meeting on May  that he intends to stay on as leader until the new one has been appointed ndash which may be at the councilrsquos annual general meeting on May .The outgoing leader said he was ldquodisappointed he did not have the support of the Conservative group but that he had led the group to the best of his ability.He said it had ldquonot been easy to protect council services amid cuts to local government funding.Delivering what promises to be his final speech as leader to full council, Cllr Thomas said he ldquodid not take up the position of leader to be popular or further my ownpolitical ambitions but instead to ensure Vale residents get the ldquobest possible services.ldquoIt would be easy to make decisions based on what the vocal minority may say in order secure votes in the next election. But what we must remember is many more vulnerable members of our society who rely on our services more than most do not have a voice and probably many of them do not use their vote.Cllr Thomas thanked councillors of all parties for ldquoputting the residents of the Vale of Glamorgan first.The leaders of Labour, Plaid Cymru and Llantwit First thanked Cllr Thomas for his work as leader and described him as ldquoco-operative.The new leader of Vale of Glamorgan Councilrsquos Conservatives has also pledged to revisit proposals on new parking charges and plans to lsquoclosersquo Llancarfan School.Cllr Vincent Bailey is in line to replace current council leader John Thomas after being elected as the leader of theConservative group on the Vale council.Two Conservative cabinet members have since resigned followingCllr Baileyrsquos election at a Conservative annual general meeting on April .Cllr Bob Penrose, the councilrsquos cabinet member for learning and culture, has resigned from the Conservatives and the ruling body with immediate effect.And Cllr Jonathan Bird, the regeneration and planning chief,has resigned from the party butremains in the cabinet as an independent.Vale council says Cllr Thomas remains the leader of the authority . The Tories have  councillors on the  member authority with  Labour members, six independents and four Plaid Cymru.Cllr Bailey, whohas been outspoken about his concerns about the car parking and Llancarfan School proposals, said: ldquoI would firstly like to take this opportunity to pay tribute to John Thomas, who has worked exceptionally hard for the Vale during his time as leader of the council and the Conservative group.ldquoI would like to thank him for all of his help and support, I look forward to working with him and other colleagues as we move forward.ldquoThe Vale of Glamorgan is a fantastic place, and fellow councillors and I look forward to delivering a bright and prosperous future for all our residents.ldquoIt is a huge honour to have been elected group leader, following a vote at the annual general meeting of the Conservative group.ldquoThe council and its employees exist to serve local people, and moving forward our priorities must include delivering progress on the Dinas Powys By-Pass, revisiting decisions to introduce car parking charges and close Llancarfan School, and looking again at the options to improve transport links between the A and J of the M. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: ride cymru bikers rev through penarth on world record bid
story: RIDE Cymru are holding a five-day charity motorcycle event around the -mile perimeter of Wales.Fty motorbikes form this group with riders and passengers dressed as daredevil stunt-performer Evel Knievel, complete with flowing capes.The fundraisers plan to journey through Penarth on Friday at around .pm, on their way from the Millennium Centre in Cardf and heading towards Barry.They will finish their journey in Wrexham on May , riding each day for over  miles and up to  hours.This year, on the final day of the ride, the RIDE Cymru will be joined by family, friends and supporters to fundraiser, the th annual five-day charity motorcycle event.The fundraisers are raising money for Macmillan Cancer Support to help people with cancer live le as fully as they can.To date the riders Pugh, Head of Services for Macmillan in Wales said: ldquoIrsquod like to say a huge thank you to RIDE Cymru for their continued fundraising for Macmillan.ldquoRIDE Cymru have such a fun time raising money for Macmillan and the support they get from the public, celebrities and legends from the biking world is testament to their enthusiasm and commitment.ldquoMacmillan relies on public donations title: two thirds of victorian lampposts in for replacement torn down
story: Victorian street lights across the town have been replaced with new modern LED units as the council says theyrsquore structurally or electrically dangerous.As the Penarth Times previously reported, more than , people have signeda petitionfounded by resident Gemma Crutchley tosave the Victorian lamp posts, fearing a ldquoloss of valuable historic character from the streetscapein Penarth.They have beenjoined by artists, politicians and other figures, including artist Haf Weighton and the Assembly Member for Cardf South and Penarth, Vaughan Gething.In March, the Conservative administration agreed to pause the replacements after agreeing with Labour to review the ldquowisdom and cost effectiveness of the scheme ndash in exchange for opposition councillors voting their budget through.Vale of Glamorgan Council leader John Thomas has confirmed just  of the  cast-iron lamp columns scheduled for replacement were still standing as of April .He told a full council meeting the LED replacement units currently being used cost pound per unit, while replacing the Victorian lamp postswith a similar type of unit would cost pound per unit.Cllr Thomas said: ldquoWe always look to fit LED lamp units on any new columns. If these columns hadnrsquot been removed public safety could have been compromised due to the seriousness of the corrosion damage on many of the column heads.Councillor Lis Burnett, who represents Penarth, told the outgoing leader ldquothere has been widespread concern in the town over the removal of these lamp posts and asked for a review of the ldquowisdom and cost effectiveness of replacing the lamp poststo be published. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
